HEADLINE: A Reluctant C.E.O. Hires His First Sales Rep

BYLINE: PAMELA RYCKMAN


HIGHLIGHT: To help him develop a strategy, Mr. Woronka decided to retain a sales consultant who recommended that he hire a full-time sales rep immediately. But he went against the consultant's advice. 

 BODY:
Last week, we published a case study recounting a dilemma faced by Action Ambulance, a provider of ambulance and transportation services to hospitals, nursing homes, rehabilitation facilities and special-education programs within school systems. The 260-employee company, which is based in Wilmington, Mass., 17 miles north of Boston, was facing increasing competition. Its chief executive, Mike Woronka, believed a more aggressive approach to sales might lure business from his seven direct competitors and also expand Action's territory.
But targeted sales, Mr. Woronka said, are unusual in his industry, where account managers generally push gently and gradually for new business. He needed to decide whether he could train his existing account managers to be more proactive or whether he would need to hire a full-time sales representative to pursue new accounts. He also considered hiring a sales manager to oversee the team.
To help him develop a strategy, Mr. Woronka decided to retain a sales consultant, Suzanne Paling, who recommended that Action hire a full-time sales rep immediately. But Mr. Woronka went against Ms. Paling's advice. He decided instead to see if his account managers had the skills and motivation to chase new clients, and he asked Ms. Paling to train them in sales. 
After eight months, it was clear that the strategy was not working. "We really struggled," Mr. Woronka said. "The account executives struggled with the system and didn't buy into the concepts, and they weren't incentivized to close deals on a straight salary. It got heated and confrontational, and people became frustrated."
Mr. Woronka let go of Ms. Paling, but he continued to be dissatisfied with his account managers' progress in sales. Two years later, he issued a mea culpa. He called Ms. Paling and asked if she would come back to help him recruit a professional sales rep.
"Because we're a small company, we were trying to manage sales in a cost-effective way," he said, "but we were putting square pegs into round holes. The whole system floundered because we didn't want to make personnel changes. Suzanne helped us to understand that an effective salesperson has to have a certain personality. Our account managers were great at their jobs, but they didn't have sales personalities."
In September 2010, Ms. Paling returned to write a job description for the professional sales representative Action needed. "Much of the work had been done," Ms. Paling said. "We'd just done it for the wrong people. Presidents or owners often assume a person with an outgoing demeanor will succeed in sales. But good salespeople are highly skilled professionals with perseverance, money motivation, the ability to prospect for new business, and the ability to close deals."
Mr. Woronka hired a sales rep with 10 years experience in pharmaceutical sales and adopted a compensation plan Ms. Paling suggested, which gave the sales rep a higher base salary for a specified training period and then switched to a lower base as she began to generate about 60 percent of her $100,000 compensation through commission. Ms. Paling stayed on for two months to ensure the new rep hit the ground running; she coached, role-played and accompanied the rep to client meetings.
As a result, Mr. Woronka said, the sales rep is thriving. "She has the right sales persona," he said. "When she's in a meeting, she's always trying to get someone to make a commitment, asking when we can come back for more. She's always looking for the close."
While Action's account managers were skeptical initially, the sales rep fit in well because responsibilities were clear up front. The rep lands accounts and immediately passes them on to the account managers, who nurture the relationships. Mr. Woronka said this proactive approach enabled Action Ambulance to prosper even in a recession. It helped increase annual revenue by at least $1.5 million (to $17 million), and last winter the company opened two new offices in Pittsfield, Mass., 143 miles from its headquarters. Mr. Woronka has been acting as the de facto sales manager, but he is now considering hiring another sales rep and a part-time sales manager.
Mr. Woronka recently discussed his decision and the results. A condensed version of the interview follows.
Q: 
Mr. Woronka: We still have one, but sadly, one passed away in December. So we've decided to hire another salesperson because I'm getting more value with the sales position than with the account management side of things.
Q: 
Mr. Woronka: We're having a tough time defining market share because our clients don't release that data. Not all the hospitals or nursing homes track the number of ambulance calls they make per month because it doesn't affect their cost structure or reimbursement. It's a vendor relationship, not a mission-critical function. But now my team is trying to define this stuff, getting to the why's behind everything instead of just going through the motions. They're thinking in terms of market share, number of beds, revenue and cost per trip. They're more engaged in asking better questions.
Q: 
Mr. Woronka: When we hired the salesperson, we had some targets we wanted to achieve in busing for special-needs kids. When she started, we were doing $4,000 of revenue per month and we've now grown that to $40,000 a month. Come September, her target is $80,000.
Q: 
Mr. Woronka: Eight or nine months ago, we got a call from one of our school districts who said a competitor had called to see if they could jump into the special-ed stuff there. The school district said they were happy with us. Now we know other people are following.
Q: 
Mr. Woronka: We're going to engage Suzanne again to hire another full-time salesperson and also a part- or quarter-time sales manager who can work with the sales force to hold them accountable, run the reports and keep them on top of building a pipeline. I don't have time as C.E.O. to do it. The salespeople and the account managers are now plugging their activities into C.R.M., so I'd envision the sales manager running the reports, viewing the activity, and meeting with them for progress updates. Because the sales force is mobile and on the road, there's no reason to have someone sitting in the office managing people who aren't there.
Q: 
Mr. Woronka: I thought that comment was interesting. It has been very difficult for us to define, but as health care evolves and changes, we're looking at new ways to differentiate ourselves. Hospitals are being forced to move patients out of their facilities with less notice than they had before. Five years ago, we knew almost 24 hours in advance that someone was going to move. Nowadays we receive 85 percent of our calls with 15 to 30 minutes notice about when patients are moving. Being in the metro-Boston area with traffic poses an interesting operational dilemma. How to get the service levels right? One thing we've done is to literally put a truck in the parking lot of hospitals we serve so we're ready to go at any time.

HEADLINE: New Poll Shows Tight Race in Michigan

BYLINE: MICHAEL D. SHEAR


HIGHLIGHT: Mitt Romney receives an endorsement from The Detroit News. 

 BODY:
A new poll of Republican voters in Michigan depicts a neck-and-neck race between Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum as Mr. Romney picks up the endorsement of one of the state's largest newspapers.
The NBC News/Marist survey shows Mr. Romney ahead with 37 percent and Mr. Santorum with 35 percent. The poll has a margin of sampling error of 4 percentage points.
The close race in the state where Mr. Romney was raised is forcing the campaign and its allies to spend millions of dollars to avoid what could be a devastating loss to Mr. Santorum on Tuesday.
Theendorsement by the Detroit News on Wednesday morning comes just as
both men are preparing to take the stage for a debate in Arizona, which also votes on Tuesday.
The newspaper said Mr. Romney was the best candidate to help the nation return to economic prosperity and had the best chance of any of the Republican hopefuls to beat President Obama in the fall.
"On leadership, the Michigan native and former Massachusetts governor has the strongest resume of the four remaining Republican candidates," the paper writes. "He has not only successfully run a state, but also has deep experience in turning around private companies. America today is the ultimate turnaround project."
Mr. Romney's opposition to the government bailout of the auto industry has been controversial in Michigan, and especially in Detroit. The newspaper criticized Mr. Romney, saying that the federal money was "absolutely essential to the survival" of the auto companies that are at the heart of the city's economy. But the paper noted that all of the Republican candidates opposed the bailout.
Instead, the newspaper focused on Mr. Romney's economic credentials and criticized Mr. Santorum's ability to deal with the country's problems.
"Nothing in his background suggests he has the skills to unify Americans behind his banner and become the leader of the free world," the paper wrote. "In addition, his fealty to the religious right will make him unappealing to the critical independent voters who will decide the election."
It's unclear whether the newspaper's endorsement will have a huge effect in the state's primary. Mr. Romney was already expected to perform well in the Detroit metropolitan area where the paper circulates. It is in the state's rural west where Mr. Romney is likely to struggle.
But the paper's nod will give Mr. Romney another talking point for the Arizona debate on Wednesday night.
In Arizona, another NBC News / Marist poll shows Mr. Romney with a double-digit lead over Mr. Santorum. That is different than a CNN/Time Magazine poll released on Tuesday which showed the race effectively tied in Arizona.

HEADLINE: The Early Word: Affirmative Action

BYLINE: JADA F. SMITH


HIGHLIGHT: Political news from today's Times, plus a look at what's happening in Washington. 

 BODY:
Today's Times

        
The Supreme Court on Tuesday signaled that it might end affirmative action in public colleges and universities, Adam Liptak reports. All sides agree that such a decision would reduce the number of African-American and Latino students at nearly every selective college and graduate school in the country, with more Asian-American and white students gaining entrance instead.

        
About two dozen individuals, couples or corporations represent a new breed of super-donor in presidential politics, each giving a million dollars or more to Republican "super PACs" this year, Nicholas Confessore, Michael Luo and Mike McIntire report. Collectively, these political action committees have given more than $50 million so far, making them the most influential and powerful donors in politics today.

        
President Obama will ask Congress to scrub the corporate tax code of dozens of loopholes and subsidies to reduce the top rate to 28 percent, while giving preferences to manufacturers that would set their maximum effective rate at 25 percent, Jackie Calmes reports.

        
Several little-noticed provisions were tucked into a $140 billion bill extending emergency jobless benefits and a temporary cut to payroll taxes, Annie Lowrey reports. Intended to modernize the country's outdated unemployment insurance system, the changes promise to aid the long-term jobless and help hold down the unemployment rate in future recessions.

        
As Newt Gingrich prepares for what may be the last debate of the primary season, his campaign has a new saying born out of frustration with two earlier lackluster debates: "Let Newt be Newt." There is a consensus in his team that his big loss in Florida was mainly because of debates in which he strained to seem above the fray, Trip Gabriel writes.

        
Mitt Romney has found himself urgently pouring resources into his home state of Michigan as Rick Santorum mounts a serious challenge there. Mr. Romney won the state handily in the last Republican presidential primary, Monica Davey reports. His trouble with Republican voters there appears to stem from a shifting political landscape and a fading, and in some cases tattered, emotional bond to the Romney name.
Happenings in Washington

        
President Obama will deliver remarks at the construction site of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture. Later, the president and first lady will host a reception in honor of the new museum's groundbreaking ceremony.

        
The National Archives will host free screenings of this year's Academy Award nominees in the Documentary Feature, Documentary Short Subject, Live Action Short Film and Animated Short Film categories. The screenings will take place in the William G. McGowan Theater and will run through Saturday.

SECTION: OPINION

LENGTH: 309 words

HEADLINE: Is Romney Reading Krugman?

BYLINE: ANDREW ROSENTHAL


HIGHLIGHT: Mitt Romney said on Tuesday that spending cuts slow the economy. 

 BODY:
At a campaign stop in Michigan on Tuesday, Mitt Romney made news by telling the truth about the economy. He said: "If you just cut, if all you're thinking about doing is cutting spending, as you cut spending you'll slow down the economy. So you have to, at the same time, create pro-growth tax policies."

The idea that spending reductions slow, rather than spur the economy is what Paul Krugman, The Times editorial board, and many liberal economists have been advancing since the downturn. (Simply put: You can't cut your way to growth.) It's also in keeping with the Obama administration's arguments. As Jack Lew, the White House chief of staff said recently on Meet the Press, "I think that there's pretty broad agreement that the time for austerity is not today Right now we have a recovery that's taking root and if we were to put in an austerity measures right now, it would take the economy in the wrong way."
Actually, there is no "broad agreement:" The Republican political establishment considers such ideas heresy. Andy Roth of the Club for Growth, called Mr. Romney's admission "hogwash." And within hours of the gaffe, campaign spokesman Ryan Williams stepped in to assure voters that Mr. Romney "believes that budget cuts-especially in the context of President Obama's unprecedented spending explosion-are a step in the right direction."
Mr. Romney's main pitch for the nomination is that he is a successful businessman who knows how to fix the economy. But when it comes to the Republican primaries, dissembling always takes precedence over expertise. If a candidate even briefly abandons ideology in favor of macroeconomic realities, he must expect attacks.

LENGTH: 1270 words

HEADLINE: Romney Details Tax Overhaul

BYLINE: JOHN HARWOOD


HIGHLIGHT: MItt Romney wants to maintain six income tax rates but lower them across the board. 

 BODY:
Mitt Romney, seeking to kick-start his presidential campaign among recalcitrant conservatives, on Wednesday proposed cutting the top income tax for individuals to 28 percent while holding out the prospect of limiting tax deductions.
Mr. Romney's earlier economic plan called only for preserving the current top tax rate of 35 percent, while holding out the promise of lower rates later in an overhaul of the tax code. But facing a major challenge from the upstart Republican rival Rick Santorum, he chose to outline such an overhaul in Arizona before critical primaries here and in Michigan next Tuesday - and before a televised debate Wednesday night in Mesa, Ariz.
At a rally in Chandler, Ariz., Mr. Romney promoted the benefits of his approach.
"In order to limit any impact on the deficit, because I do not want to add to the deficit, and also to make sure we continue to have progressivity in our tax code, I'm going to limit the deductions and exemptions, particularly for high-income folks," Mr. Romney, a former governor of Massachusetts, said.
"And by the way, I want to make sure that you understand, for middle-income families, the deductibility of home mortgage interest and charitable contributions, those things will continue," he said. "For high-income folks, we are going to cut back on that, so we make sure that the top 1 percent keeps paying the current share they're paying or more. We want middle-income Americans to be the place we focus our help, because its middle-income Americans that have been hurt by this Obama economy."
Mr. Romney's top economic adviser, Glenn Hubbard, said the plan would cut all six current tax brackets - 10 percent, 15 percent, 25 percent, 28 percent, 33 percent, 35 percent, depending on a taxpayer's income - by the same proportion of 20 percent. That would produce this new set of tax brackets: 8 percent, 12 percent, 20 percent, 22.4 percent, 26.4 percent, and 28 percent. "It's a marginal rate cut for every American," Mr. Hubbard said.
But echoing the candidate, he added that Mr. Romney was committed to making his plan both "revenue neutral" - meaning it won't add to the budget deficit -- and "distributionally neutral" - meaning that it won't shift the tax burden from upper-income Americans to middle- and working-class Americans. Since the largest benefits from rate reduction would go to upper-income taxpayers, they will also bear the burdens of "base broadening" reductions in existing deductions needed to keep the government from hemorrhaging revenue, he explained.
Reducing large tax deductions, like the ones for home mortgage interest and state and local taxes, can be politically treacherous because of their popularity with voters and elected officials alike. For now, at least, Mr. Romney will dodge any potential backlash by avoiding such specifics.
Mr. Romney will pledge to work with Congress on "limiting them," Mr. Hubbard said, but "it is not his intention to take on any specific
deduction or exclusion and eliminate it."
Mr. Romney has praised the work of President Obama'sSimpson-Bowles deficit reduction commission, but criticized the president for ignoring its work. Mr. Romney, however, is also rejecting the commission's recommendation that tax overhaul produce increased government revenue to cut the deficit, while embracing its recommendation to cut the top tax rate to 29 percent or lower.
Mr. Hubbard contrasted Mr. Romney's "pro-growth" plan with Mr. Obama's proposal to raise taxes on individuals earning more than $200,000 and households earning more than $250,000. He argued that would hurt economic growth by crimping small businesses, many of which file under the individual tax code.
Mr. Hubbard, who was an economic adviser to President George W. Bush and is now dean of the business school at Columbia University, also cast the
Romney plan as superior to Mr. Santorum's. Mr. Santorum would also cut the top individual rate to 28 percent, the level it reached after Congress and the White House agreed on a tax overhaul plan during the Reagan presidency, while preserving only one more tax bracket of 10 percent. In the name of "national security," Mr. Santorum has also proposed a zero tax rate for manufacturing businesses as a means of preserving and expanding that economic sector.
The Santorum plan would significantly expand the budget deficit, Mr. Hubbard said, and the zero rate for manufacturing would result in "significant capital misallocation."
"Net-net, it's a job destroyer, not a job creator," Mr. Hubbard said.
Both Mr. Santorum and former Speaker Newt Gingrich, who has proposed an optional "flat tax" system of 15 percent, have accused Mr. Romney of timidity. With his new proposal, Mr. Romney seeks to counter that charge in advance of Wednesday night's debate.
Mr. Romney's plan aims to balance two competing priorities of different Republican factions. By proposing to cut the top rate, he
is seeking support among supply-side conservatives who contend that lower marginal rates are the key ingredient for producing economic growth.
But by vowing to offset the loss of revenue by eliminating some deductions, he is addressing concerns among deficit hawks about expanding the tide of red ink that has the federal government spending an estimated $1.3 trillion more than it takes in this year.
And by insisting that those unspecified reductions will fall most heavily on the affluent, he is seeking to limit a line of attack that portrays him as a wealthy former financial industry executive who himself has paid taxes at only around the 15 percent rate because most of his income comes from capital gains. Mr. Romney would maintain the current 15 percent rate on dividends and capital gains.
Mr. Obama has proposed to tax the "carried interest" received by many hedge fund and private equity executives at higher ordinary income rates rather than as capital gains, arguing that current law gives them an undue advantage. Mr. Romney himself has benefited handsomely from that.
Mr. Hubbard said a President Romney would ask his treasury secretary to study the "devilishly hard question" of whether current law should change and tax some of that income at ordinary income rates.
Mr. Romney had proposed eliminating capital gains taxes on taxpayers earning less than $200,000, but that drew fire from some conservatives and campaign rivals like Mr. Gingrich on the grounds that it gave unwarranted preference to a specific group and would have small economic impact since those taxpayers receive relatively little in capital gains anyway.
Mr. Romney also proposes to eliminate both the estate tax and the alternative minimum tax, while cutting the top corporate tax rate to 25 percent from 35 percent.
Mr. Hubbard said three different revenue streams would keep the plan from increasing the budget deficit: the "dynamic" effects of economic growth, the additional income that would be subject to taxation through "base broadening," and spending cuts Mr. Romney plans that would reach $500 billion per year by 2016. The campaign promised more specifics on those spending cuts within the next week.
 In advance of Mr. Romney's tax plan, Mr. Obama's Treasury Department on Wednesday proposed its own corporate tax overhaul plan cutting the top corporate rate to 28 percent by eliminating some existing corporate deductions. Part of the Obama plan includes a minimum tax on the overseas income of United States-based corporations. 
Mr. Hubbard, accusing the administration of a "full-throttle attack on multinationals", said Mr. Romney would propose shifting to a territorial system that would not tax corporate income earned overseas.

LENGTH: 1384 words

HEADLINE: Who Decided That This Election Should Be About Sex?

BYLINE: DAVID BROOKS and GAIL COLLINS


HIGHLIGHT: Brooks and Collins discuss the surprising role debates over contraception, abortion and unwed mothers have played so far in the campaign. 

 BODY:
Gail Collins: David, if you had asked me what the big topic of the presidential race was going to be, I'd certainly have said jobs, jobs, jobs. But lately, we seem to be talking about women, women, women.
David Brooks: With an opening like that I'm suddenly having flashbacks to the Clinton years.
Gail: In Washington they're fighting about whether it's a good plan to have all-male panels discussing women's right to get contraceptives under their health insurance. In Virginia they're debating abortion and Mississippi is thinking about bringing back the personhood amendment its voters defeated last year. In Indiana this week there was a dust-up in the State Legislature over the Girl Scouts, and whether they promote abortion and homosexuality.
And of course, the Republican presidential campaign is all over it. You'll have to explain to me whether you think Rick Santorum believes that talking about the evils of prenatal testing is good for his campaign or whether he just can't help himself.
David: Oh, that kind of women's issue. Less Paula Jones, more Bob Jones. I guess my reaction to all these issues is that they are getting more and more fringey. For a few decades we had knockdown, drag-out fights about how the sexual revolution was going to shake out, but now it's sort of a done deal.
We've reached a national consensus. People in the educated class talk like social progressives and behave like traditionalists. People in the less educated classes talk like social conservatives and behave like libertines. Nearly everybody is cool with things like contraception. Most people want to restrict abortion without making it impossible and we're kind of exhausted by the fight that never goes anywhere.
To me the thing that took the stuffing out of the culture wars is that the social fabric began to repair. Teenage pregnancy rates are down. Abortion rates are down. Crime is down. There are problems with the social fabric but they no longer have to do with the sexual revolution.
When Rick Santorum talks about this stuff in the way he does, it's theology, not sociology. And believe me, there are very few Americans who are strongly theological, even the ones who attend services every week.
Gail: I'm being driven crazy by people who are obsessed with limiting the scope of government, but feel perfectly free to demand that government get involved in women's most personal choices. How can they argue that the states have no right to meddle in , then cheer for the states to pass laws telling a doctor to perform a stupendously invasive procedure like a pelvic ultrasound on an unwilling patient who wants to get a first trimester abortion?
Okay, I'm done. Calming down and moving forward.
David: Moving forward? Please don't tell me you got a contract with MSNBC. Isn't that their slogan? Or is it Lean Forward? Why would MSNBC be content with leaning? Shouldn't they be marching forward? Leaning sounds so inebriated.
(Don't mind me, I'm just trying to change the subject from Santorum's position on prenatal testing.)
Gail: Whenever you bring up women's internal workings, guys want to change the subject. Unless, of course, they're trying to change the laws.
David: As to your larger point, I do think it's consistent to be economically libertarian and socially paternalistic. In fact I'd argue dynamic capitalism requires a stringent and coherent social order to help guard against its savageries - tight families to educate children, anti-materialist values to police rampant consumerism, a spiritual public square to mitigate the corrosive culture of greedy self-interest.
Free market beliefs and socially conservative beliefs require each other, so long as those socially conservative beliefs are traditional, not theological. I'm for traditional values, with government playing a small role to support them. I get worried when some politician begins trying to legislate his faith's version of Natural Law.
Gail: I'm not sure whether this obsessing about sex works for Santorum, but I suspect that it's really bad for the anti-abortion movement. Its leaders have been very canny in trying to present the debate as a fight over whether a doctor can dismember a fully developed fetus. And they were doing pretty well, politically.
Now the debate is about things like contraception, fertilization treatments and prenatal testing. A vast majority of Americans don't regard any of these things as immoral. And the fact that we're arguing about them highlights the critical fact that convictions about precisely exactly when a new life begins - fertilization? implantation? quickening? birth? - are both deeply personal and deeply theological.
David: I guess that's true but the anti-abortion movement seems pretty healthy. The way I read the polls young people are moving way left on same-sex marriage and slightly right on abortion. Of course most people like me are in the squishy middle.
Gail: But I know the woman-related news that most interests you is the new government data on the rise of unwed mothers. It seems likely that pretty soon most American children will be born to unmarried women. The big argument seems to be whether this is a result of the lack of good-paying blue collar jobs or a split in our society, in which the bottom third - or half or two-thirds - lead lives that are too chaotic for long-term relationships.
David: I've tried to argue that it's both. It's a spiral of economic and social influences that are impossible to untangle. As one social scientist put it, what nature hath joined together, multiple regression cannot put asunder.
Gail: There's a really good book on this subject called "Promises I Can Keep," by Kathryn Edin and Maria Kefalas. They concluded that low-income women saw marriage not as the beginning of their lives, but as the payoff. They intended to wait until they had put together enough resources to have a nice wedding, and then live in a good place of their own. They were also, of course, waiting to find a man who was settled and stable enough to be a good husband.
In some ways they weren't different from college-educated women, who tended to put off marriage until they'd gotten their careers off the ground. The difference was that the poorer women regarded marriage as a reward, but children as a necessity. They weren't prepared to defer motherhood the way their better educated peers were.
David: I'm so glad you mentioned that book. I've been hoping to plug it in a column. It is indeed really good. I do think that the life script that many low-income women envision is simply not correct, though. As you say, they see marriage as a culmination. They have kids, get a good job and make some money, and then they can afford the lovely wedding. That's backward. For most people getting married is not the payoff after an upward climb it's the tool to advance the upward climb.
Married people save money. Married people have more settled habits. Married men are much more stable. When people marry first they are more likely to make it later.
Gail: That presumes you can find a settled guy with a good job to marry. I doubt many single mothers have rejected a whole bunch of those prospects.
David: Agreed - this doesn't solve the other problem, which is what do we do to make it so that more men are worth marrying. But I do think Barack Obama should start a public information campaign that says that people should marry before they have kids, not after. This is one thing Rick Santorum gets right. People who marry before childbearing, graduate from high school and get a job, any job, do not live in poverty. That's what we need to encourage.
Gail: You may be right that the big issue for America now is class, not race or gender. But in this presidential campaign, gender rules. Really, sex rules. Who'd have thought?
David: Class is gender. Specifically men. The wage stagnation and inequality stories are largely stories about how badly men have been doing over the past few decades. Women's incomes have been up, up, up.
So let's return to our normal subject. Men, men, men. Let's go back and have a normal election: men talking about themselves. The love that won't shut up.

LENGTH: 625 words

HEADLINE: Your Midweek News Links

BYLINE: MARK BITTMAN


HIGHLIGHT: Your midweek news roundup. 

 BODY:
Bon Appetit Management Company, which I wrote about in May, has promised to phase out pork produced in gestation crates, do away with all eggs from confined hens and source at least 25 percent of its meat from farms that are third-party certified humane by 2015. This sets the bar for animal welfare for major food service providers in the United States. Bon Appetit is owned by The Compass Group, which should direct all of its subsidiaries to follow this lead.

In Tracie McMillan's (excellent) new book, "The American Way of Eating: Undercover at Walmart, Applebee's, Farm Fields and the Dinner Table,"the author goes undercover to work at the bottom of the American food chain. Here, here and here are excerpts. Meanwhile, in a survey of 30,000 workers in all fields, 42.3 percent of fast food workers said, "My job may make the world a worse place." (The next highest-ranked profession was "bartender," with only 5.8 percent.) McDonald's may be the world's largest fast food chain, but Ad Age reports that the behemoth usually ranks near the bottom in quality perception when compared with rivals. Speaking of burgers, it was bound to happen: a patron at the Heart Attack Grill in Las Vegas, which specializes in a 6,000 calorie "Triple Bypass Burger," had a heart attack while eating in the dining room.
And Congresswoman Louise Slaughter (D-NY) sent a letter to more than 60 of the leading fast food companies, meat producers and grocery stories asking them to release details on their antibiotic use policies.
The local food ordinance movement that began in a handful of small towns in Maine has found its way to California, where the El Dorado County Board of Supervisors have signaled support for a "Local Food and Community Self-Governance" ordinance.
Anthony DeBenedet at Time Ideas says the new national focus on preventing obesity may be creating eating disorders in young girls. Gotta fix that.
The U.S. and the European Union will soon treat each other's organic standards as equivalent. Organic food companies are cheering because their potential markets just doubled. On the flip side, Reuters reports that European farmers are likely to fall behind in the competitive world grain market as E.U. consumer hostility to GMOs drives away research and prevents cultivation of high-yield and pest-resistant crops.
A French court has declared Monsanto guilty of chemically poisoning a French grain grower who says he suffered memory loss, headaches and stammering after inhaling Monsanto's Lasso weedkiller in 2004.
President Obama is seeking a 17 percent bump for the F.D.A. budget for Fiscal Year 2013, and nearly all of that increase would come from upping industry fees. Here's one thing the F.D.A. could do with that money: Rep. Frank Pallone (D-NJ) and Rep. Rosa DeLauro (D-CT) introduced a House bill that would require the F.D.A. to set safety standards for arsenic and lead in juices. It's called the "Arsenic Prevention and Protection from Lead Exposure in Juice Act of 2012": the APPLE Juice Act.
School meal news: An U.S.D.A. inspector performing nutrition checks on the lunches of a preschool class in North Carolina decided that a four-year-old's lunch-consisting of a turkey-and-cheese sandwich, a banana, potato chips and apple juice-wasn't nutritious enough, so the child was given three chicken nuggets instead.
PepsiCo has made a killing by selling orange juice diluted with water and calling it "Trop 50."
A vaccine against Salmonella may be one step closer, according to a research team led by a U.C. Davis immunologist.
Researchers may have found a link between memory loss and a high-calorie diet.

HEADLINE: Are Manufacturers Really Special?

BYLINE: ANNIE LOWREY


HIGHLIGHT: The Obama administration's proposal for an overhaul of corporate tax rates includes new breaks aimed at promoting manufacturing jobs. Policy experts have long been divided as to whether manufacturing deserves such cultivation. 

 BODY:
The Obama administration is undertaking an athletic push to promote manufacturing employment in the United States: proposing giving manufacturers new tax breaks, closing loopholes that benefit companies that send manufacturing jobs offshore, expanding worker training programs and increasing trade enforcement, for instance.
The administration underscored manufacturing's first-among-equals status when announcing its proposed overhaul of the corporate tax code on Wednesday. "It's a framework that lowers the corporate tax rate and broadens the tax base in order to increase competitiveness for companies across the nation," President Obama said in a statement. "It cuts tax rates even further for manufacturers that are creating new products and manufacturing goods here in America."
But what's so special about manufacturing? Is there really a reason for the White House to champion that certain set of businesses? Why not services? Or another growing sector of the economy, like agriculture?
Policy experts have long been divided on these questions. Many economists argue that there's nothing special about manufacturing, and that Mr. Obama's proposals are simply an election-year sop. They note that plenty of nonmanufacturing businesses are highly innovative. Moreover, they argue that relatively high wages for American workers mean that manufacturing employment - though it has rebounded in the last two years - is never really coming back.
But others say the United States can create, retain and regain higher-end manufacturing jobs. They also argue that manufacturing has potent spillover effects that make it worthwhile for the government to promote.

A new paper by the Brookings Institution's Metropolitan Policy Program lays out the case for manufacturing exceptionalism in detail. The report, by Susan Helper, Timothy Krueger and Howard Wial, puts forward four main arguments.
First, it argues that manufacturing "provides high-wage jobs, especially for workers who would otherwise earn the lowest wages." To show that, the study controls for workers' personal characteristics, like their level of education, to compare similar workers in different industries. The researchers find that wages tend to be higher for manufacturing workers than for nonmanufacturing workers, perhaps because manufacturers are willing to pay to retain higher-skilled employees. It is a point the administration echoes when it says that manufacturing will be an important source of middle-class jobs.
Second, the paper argues that manufacturing is important for innovation. Manufacturers tend to plow significant funds into research and development, much more so than other businesses in the private sector. Though manufacturing makes up about 11 percent of economic output, the paper says, manufacturing businesses account for 68 percent of the research and development spending by domestic business.
But why not keep research, development and innovation onshore while offshoring the hard work of putting garments or cars or rockets together? The paper cites studies showing that the "co-location" of research and production are important for improving business practices and generating innovation. It also argues that that manufacturers' innovation and research can spill over to other workers and firms.
"The interdependence between production and innovation is apparent in many industries, and policy makers ignore this fact at the peril of eroding America's competitive edge in both current and future industries and in services as well as manufacturing," the study says. 
Finally, the paper argues that manufacturing can help reduce the country's trade deficit, and that smart manufacturing can promote environmental sustainability.
On the other side, economists argue that such claims about manufacturing are overstated: that most manufacturing jobs will be low-wage and low-end and therefore will go overwhelmingly to workers overseas; that other businesses foster innovation as well; and that there are many more solidly middle-class jobs to be found in the service sector. 
One way or another, it is undeniable that manufacturing employment is growing, even if that is just a bounce back from the depths of the recession. The economy has added about 330,000 manufacturing jobs in the last two years.

LENGTH: 932 words

HEADLINE: What to Watch for in Tonight's Debate

BYLINE: MICHAEL D. SHEAR


HIGHLIGHT: In all of the Republican debates over the past year, Rick Santorum has never been at center stage. That will change. 

 BODY:
In the numerous televised debates among Republican candidates during the past year, Rick Santorum has never been at center stage. That changes Wednesday night.
Mr. Santorum, a former senator from Pennsylvania, is taking his turn as the principal opponent for Mitt Romney during a debate in Arizona hosted by CNN and moderated by John King, one of the network's anchors. The debate, which will also include Ron Paul and Newt Gingrich, starts at 8 p.m. Eastern time.
For Mr. Santorum, the debate will be his final opportunity to offer his message nationally in advance of next Tuesday's primaries in Arizona and Michigan. And it will offer the most risk that a stumble
or gaffe could put the brakes on his recent momentum in those states.
Aides to Mr. Santorum are aware of his need to avoid mistakes and project a broad appeal to voters who have reservations about choosing Mr. Romney as the standard-bearer of the party.
But they are also eager to see Mr. Santorum go after what they believe are Mr. Romney's vulnerabilities with conservative voters.
"The Tea Party and that movement exists because of four things: Obamacare, the big bank bailout, cap-and-tax legislation and immigration," Hogan Gidley, a top adviser to Mr. Santorum, said in an interview. "Mitt Romney joined with Barack Obama on all of those key issues."
Mr. Romney has been one of the most consistent performers during the debates, remaining cool for most of them and turning aggressive toward his rivals when his campaign was eager for him to show that he can fight back.
The pressure on Mr. Romney to win on Tuesday, especially in Michigan, the state in which he grew up, suggests that Mr. Romney could be more like the aggressive debater he was during the two debates before the Florida primary last month.
But there have also been moments when Mr. Romney got rattled, a fact that could encourage his rivals on the stage to attack repeatedly.
The other two candidates on the stage also have challenges. Newt Gingrich has managed to steal the show during previous debates by railing against the media and liberals. If he can do that again, he might re-enter the conversation.
Mr. Paul rarely varies from his policy script -- freedom, liberty, an end to the Federal Reserve, and the occasional complaint about not being asked enough questions. He's likely to continue that.
Here are some other things to look for during the debate:
TAXES: Mr. Romney's new tax proposals, unveiled Wednesday, for lower individual rates should prompt a discussion among the candidates about whose plan would benefit Americans the most. Mr. Santorum has argued for a zero corporate tax rate on manufacturing and Mr. Gingrich has advocated an optional 15 percent flat tax.
RELIGION AND BIRTH CONTROL: This will be the first debate since the controversy over President Obama's decision to require religious institutions to provide free access to birth control. The decision - since amended - has prompted a robust discussion on the campaign trail about the tradeoffs between religious liberty and the provision of health care. And it has sparked a renewed debate about cultural issues like abortion and contraception.
THE AUTO BAILOUT: With the race in Michigan apparently very close between Mr. Romney and Mr. Santorum, questions about the government auto bailout are inevitable. All of the candidates on the stage opposed the auto bailout, but Mr. Romney has been under the most pressure for saying at the time that the companies should be allowed to enter a managed bankruptcy without a bailout.
HEALTH CARE: Mr. Santorum has been relentless in his pursuit of Mr. Romney on health care in previous debates. He accuses Mr. Romney of having been the inspiration for Mr. Obama's health care proposals, a charge that has gotten Mr. Romney angry and even flustered at times. Look for Mr. Santorum to try to repeat that effort.
IRAN AND ISRAEL: The heightened tension over Iran's pursuit of a nuclear program is almost sure to mean a discussion. It will also be one of the opportunities for the candidates on the stage to criticize Mr. Obama as much as they criticize each other. Most of the candidates (Mr. Paul being the exception) have urged a more aggressive posture against Iran.
GAS PRICES: Republicans have clearly decided to seize on rising oil and gas prices as a way to hammer Mr. Obama's economic policies. The debate should offer a platform for their arguments that the president has not done enough to expand domestic oil production in an effort to keep prices down. Mr. Gingrich, in particular, has made this a central theme in recent days and has even released a 30-minute video speech about gas prices that his campaign says he will pay to run in several markets in the coming weeks.
IMMIGRATION: The issue of illegal immigration has not come up in a big way recently on the campaign trail. But the debate is being held in Arizona, a border state where the issue is critical to many of the state's voters. Look for the candidates to seize the mantle of the man who is toughest on the issue.
INSIDER vs. OUTSIDER: All of the candidates are trying to stress that they would shake up Washington, a city that remains anathema to many conservative voters. Mr. Romney, in particular, has been trying to portray both Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Santorum as insiders because of their long careers in Congress. Look for him to continue that theme during the debate.

SECTION: US; politics

LENGTH: 676 words

HEADLINE: Santorum Sees 'Evil Forces' Confronting America

BYLINE: KATHARINE Q. SEELYE


HIGHLIGHT: Rick Santorum echoes his remarks about Satan going after the United States. 

 BODY:
TUCSON -- Rick Santorum gives the impression of a man on a roll; while he surges in the polls, his crowds swell and his speechifying becomes more expansive.
 He held a Tea Party crowd here rapt for an hour on Wednesday while he took inventory of multiple items in the conservative cabinet and derided President Obama at every turn.
 In fact, Mr. Santorum seems to have mentally skated past Mitt Romney and the other Republicans he must still defeat in the primary in order to win the presidential nomination and is already taking the fight to President Obama.
 The president, he said, was "making the world a much more dangerous place." Mr. Santorum, who was criticized earlier this week for having said in a 2008 speech that Satan had set his sights on the United States, took ownership of that concept Wednesday, asserting that there are indeed "evil forces" around the world.
 "And yet our president refuses to call evil evil, refuses to even name it, refuses to confront it, tries to appease and cajole it in an effort to reduce America's commitments around the world," he declared.
 He also accused the president of "systematically trying to crush the traditional Judeo-Christian principles in this country" and said Mr. Obama was trying to impose his moral values on the country with the enactment of his health care plan.
 Mr. Santorum hopes that his hardline stance on various issues will convince voters that he can present the sharpest contrast to Mr. Obama in the fall. If Mr. Santorum becomes the Republican nominee and he carries over the substance and tone of his recent speeches, Mr. Obama seems in for a fight far uglier than he encountered in 2008.
 Mr. Santorum's references to Mr. Romney, who still leads the Republican field in delegates, were fleeting. He asked the crowd at one point who they trusted, a "Johnny-come-lately" to the conservative cause (no names necessary), "or the guy on a high-wire line who tells you what's in his heart, what's in his gut?"
 He said that Mr. Romney's recently issued tax plan was a copy of his own. ("Welcome to the party, governor, he said. "Great to have you along.")
 Mr. Santorum distinguished himself from other Republicans by saying he favored supply-side economics but only if it works "for the working man as well as folks at the top of the scale." Mr. Obama's economic plan, he said, "is food stamps and more dependency."
 The president, he added, had a "radical environmental ideology" that opposes drilling for oil in Alaska. "In my administration, we will drill for oil in Alaska," he declared. High gas prices affect everyone, he said, even those "who the President says he cares about -- he cares about them enough to get them addicted on government programs so he can get their vote when election time comes."
 He also chastised the left for thinking that the pursuit of happiness, as described in the Declaration of Independence, meant that people could do whatever they wanted.
 "True happiness," he counseled, "comes from doing what you ought to do," referring to God's will.
 "This is what I know gets everybody on the secular left just bonkers about my campaign," he said. "They just go crazy, because I say that America is, at its heart, a moral enterprise."
 Here in the southern part of Arizona, not far from the Mexican border, immigration is a major issue. "There's no bigger issue of national security than securing the southern border of this country," Mr. Santorum said.
 "You have my pledge that we will secure this border, we will deal with the issue of the drug violence and the cartels, we will work with the Mexican government," he said, "so that people in Arizona can live in peace and prosperity just like every other state in the county."
 The event was held in a Shriners' hall here in the Congressional district that Gabrielle Giffords represented until she resigned a few weeks ago as she continues to recover from having been shot in the head last year. A heated race is now underway for her seat. Mr. Santorum did not mention her name.
