HEADLINE: The Big Cheesy, a Grilled Cheese Sandwich Challenge

BYLINE: By RACHEL LEE HARRIS

 BODY:
One of the first things I learned as a young Miser was how to make a grilled cheese sandwich: one slice of good old American cheese on one thin piece of white bread, baked open-faced on the top rack of the oven until little brown and black blisters formed on the top (my favorite part).
As a child, Brian Keyser, proprietor of Casellula Cheese & Wine Cafe, used Kraft slices or, on special occasions, factory-made cheddar or jack. ''Not that there is anything wrong with that,'' he wrote in an e-mail. ''O.K., there is. I would be disappointed, to say the least, to have to eat that now.'' 
That's because at Casellula he serves a variety of international cheeses with complex flavors. Like a good sommelier, he freely shares his passion for, and knowledge of, the subject. ''Cheeses, which are alive, are filled with living organisms that add flavor and change it over time,'' he said. ''In these hard economic times cheese is an affordable way to indulge. Eating handmade cheese is a great way to support small farms. I could go on and discuss its nutritional value and its many proven aphrodisiac qualities, but I don't want to bore you.''
Bore me? Bring on the fondue!
And Mr. Keyser will, this Saturday and Sunday, when he presents his fondue grilled cheese, accompanied by pickled-pepper relish, at the Big Cheesy, a grilled cheese sandwich competition to find the best in the city, sponsored by Openhouse Gallery, a pop-up event-planning organization. The $25 ticket allows fromage heads to vote for their favorite of seven varieties of grilled cheese from shops all over New York, including the popular Murray's Cheese in the West Village. You can wash them down with a beer from Sixpoint Craft Ales and soft drinks provided by Bella Lula.
''We focus on pairing cheese with other ingredients that will bring out its flavor,'' Adam Schneider, a co-owner of Little Muenster on the Lower East Side, wrote. His partner, Vanessa Palazio, grew up on the Nicaraguan repocheta: two tortillas with queso fresco. This weekend they plan to present a three-cheese melt with butternut squash puree and sage brown butter.
The Melt Shop's managing partner, Spencer Rubin, used to make his grills on French bread turned inside-out, with salted butter, pressed down with a white plate on the stove top. ''I'm salivating just thinking about it,'' he wrote. His offering for this weekend is still in the experimental phase, and he's keeping the recipe on lockdown until it's perfected. ''I have been working with this great cranberry pepper jelly.''
As for Mr. Keyser, he plans to win using Scharfer Max, a slightly stinky, washed-rind Alpine cheese that has a distinct oniony note to it. ''Our worthy competition are welcome to see the recipe and tremble in fear,'' he said.
(The Big Cheesy, 1 to 7 p.m., 201 Mulberry Street, between Spring and Delancey Streets, Little Italy; advance purchase is recommended (Saturday is sold out; a few tickets are available for Sunday); 212-334-0288, openhousegallery.org.)
FIELD TRIPS FOR YOUNG FOODIES
Children who'd like to devise their own specialty sandwiches one day should persuade their teachers to sign up for a field trip to the Brooklyn Kitchen. Every other Thursday the Kitchen hosts a tour of its site, a butchery demonstration at the Meat Hook butcher shop, a lecture on where food comes from and a cooking class. Any New York City school is eligible with a $5 donation from each child. (Waivers are available on request.)
(100 Frost Street, between Leonard Street and Manhattan Avenue, Williamsburg; 718-389-2982, classroomsinthekitchen@thebrooklynkitchen.com)

HEADLINE: A Fund-Raiser Faces Inquiries Into His Races

BYLINE: By ERIC LICHTBLAU

 BODY:
WASHINGTON -- Last year, House Republican leaders tapped an up-and-coming Florida lawmaker, Representative Vern Buchanan, to lead the party's fund-raising for candidates nationwide, a crucial part of their efforts to keep control of the House in November.
The drive has already paid dividends in surging donations. Now, however, Mr. Buchanan's golden touch in raising money could prove as much a hindrance as an asset, as a thicket of questions surrounding his own Florida campaigns is threatening to distract from the Republicans' national finance operation.
Federal inquiries surrounding Mr. Buchanan appear to be widening, as investigators examine allegations that his companies improperly reimbursed contributors to his campaigns and claimed improper tax deductions and that he failed to include all his varied financial interests in his Congressional disclosure reports.
The Federal Election Commission has already completed one investigation that produced a settlement this week with a former partner of Mr. Buchanan's who used their car dealership to reimburse employees for contributing to the congressman's campaigns, in violation of federal law. 
The commission dropped its case against Mr. Buchanan himself over the reimbursements, despite testimony that he took part in the scheme. But agents for the F.B.I. and the Internal Revenue Service recently contacted former employees alleging financial improprieties by Mr. Buchanan, who owns a number of auto dealerships thoughout Florida and elsewhere and is one of the richest members of Congress.
A federal grand jury in Tampa is hearing evidence in the case as well, according to several people with knowledge of the inquiries.
The House Ethics Committee, meanwhile, is examining his failure in Congressional filings to disclose numerous financial interests and management positions -- 17 in all -- in another car dealership, a Florida development company, his own family foundation and other organizations. He also failed to report $11,000 in income from at least one of these companies.
Blaming accounting oversights, Mr. Buchanan filed four years' worth of new House disclosure statements last September, belatedly acknowledging these financial interests. But a review of campaign finance reports shows a deep link between his newly disclosed corporate interests and his own fund-raising operations, with donors affiliated with these groups donating more than $136,000 to his campaigns.
The congressman's lawyers predicted he would be exonerated and said the allegations against him were driven by disgruntled former employees and opponents.
''His political enemies are growing increasingly desperate and making all these accusations against him,'' said William J. McGinley, a Washington lawyer representing the congressman. ''It's a political witch hunt.''
One important question is whether high-pressure solicitations for donations from Mr. Buchanan's business partners and employees crossed the line into duress.
While some employees said in interviews that they had given donations freely, others said they contributed after aggressive solicitations by Mr. Buchanan.
Christopher Narvaez, who was chief financial officer at one of Mr. Buchanan's auto dealerships in the mid-2000s, said in an interview that before Mr. Buchanan announced his Congressional candidacy in 2005, he strongly encouraged company executives to contribute.
Mr. Narvaez said that at one meeting with partners and executives, Mr. Buchanan said: ''I really need you to give the maximum allowance to get the campaign off to a good start.''
Afterward, Mr. Narvaez said, Mr. Buchanan approached him in the hallway several times and asked, ''Have you made your contribution yet?'' (He eventually did, but not the maximum.)
Questions about Mr. Buchanan's finances have percolated in the Florida news media and political circles there for three years. But they have received little attention nationally, despite his rising profile as both chairman of the finance team for the National Republican Congressional Committee and a member of the powerful House Ways and Means Committee.
That could change, however, as inquiries by the Ethics Committee and others press on.
''In terms of perception, the Republicans have to be concerned,'' said Daniel A. Smith, a University of Florida political science professor who has followed the Buchanan case closely. ''This certainly may not be the face that you want raising money for the Republican Party.''
No evidence of impropriety has surfaced in what has been a hugely successful national fund-raising operation for the House Republicans.
With President Obama's economic record as a main target, the House Republican committee raised $54.1 million last year in the effort to defend their House majority -- a spike of 49 percent over the same point before the 2010 elections, data show.
''Congressman Buchanan has been a valuable part of our success in raising the resources we need to combat the hundreds of millions of dollars that Democrat special interests are investing to return Nancy Pelosi to the speaker's chair,'' said Paul Lindsay, spokesman for the Republican committee. ''This committee has always maintained a strict legal compliance with the letter and the spirit of the law.''
Mr. Buchanan's office, based in Sarasota, did not respond to requests for an interview.
His supporters say that as a self-made businessman, Mr. Buchanan brings a built-in credibility with prospective donors about creating jobs and lowering taxes, and his influence is particularly important in the Florida battleground.
Steve Hiteman, who worked as chief financial officer for a Buchanan auto company, described him as a ''charismatic'' leader inspiring loyalty.
''You don't want to let him down,'' Mr. Hiteman, who along with his wife has given at least $17,000 to Mr. Buchanan's campaigns, said in an interview. He added quickly: ''I was never coerced or strong-armed in any way -- no deals, no nothing.''
Others tell a different story.
The election commission's investigation established that three of Mr. Buchanan's Florida dealerships used corporate money to reimburse employees for tens of thousands of dollars in contributions to his 2006 and 2008 campaigns.
Some executives and employees, who donated thousands of dollars each after rarely, if ever, making a contribution before, said they were reimbursed through cash ''bonuses,'' or offered trips on Mr. Buchanan's corporate jet and to his Colorado home, according the commission's investigation.
Commission investigators also found that the reimbursed contributions were part of an ''extensive and ongoing scheme'' by the Hyundai of North Jacksonville dealership to hide the source of the donations, in violation of federal law. Initially, the commission's general counsel tied the fund-raising methods directly to Mr. Buchanan, finding he ''knowingly and willfully'' accepted the improper contributions, according to internal investigative reports that the commission made public just last month.
One former Buchanan executive, Salvatore Rosa, told investigators that reimbursements began as far back as 2003. He said Mr. Buchanan pressured employees to attend a $1,000-a-person fund-raiser for President George W. Bush's 2004 re-election campaign and instructed Mr. Rosa to reimburse them.
When he objected to the reimbursements as illegal, Mr. Rosa said Mr. Buchanan told him to ''finesse it,'' according to his statement to commission investigators.
In a separate civil deposition last month, Mr. Rosa also said that the congressman took part in a ''conspiracy to evade U.S. income taxes'' through improper business deductions and accounting methods, and Mr. Rosa has brought a complaint with the I.R.S. that would award him part of any money recovered. The agency declined to comment.
Beyond Mr. Rosa, other former partners and employees also maintain that Mr. Buchanan personally directed the reimbursements at different dealerships.
But Mr. Buchanan's lawyers have attacked the credibility of his accusers, describing them as bitter former employees, and they said Mr. Buchanan knew nothing of the improper payments.
Despite its initial findings against Mr. Buchanan, the election commission ultimately back-tracked and decided last February to drop the case against him, notifying his lawyers they were closing the file.
The commission reached a small monetary settlement this week with one of Mr. Buchanan's former partners, Sam Kazran, finding that he used money from the Jacksonville Hyundai dealership they owned to contribute nearly $68,000 to Mr. Buchanan's campaigns.
The congressman's lawyer, Mr. McGinley, said the election commission agreement should put an end to ''false allegations'' that Mr. Buchanan directed or knew of the improper reimbursements.
But critics remain unconvinced.
Melanie Sloan, executive director of the Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, a nonpartisan group that brought an ethics complaint against Mr. Buchanan and represents a former employee, said the flurry of recent activity surrounding the case left her hopeful that the Justice Department or the House Ethics Committee might move against him.
''There's so much evidence in this case,'' she said. ''It's not just one or two things; there's a lot of smoke, and a lot of his employees are talking about him. You don't have to believe us.''

HEADLINE: Romney's Economic Closet

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN

 BODY:
According to Michael Kinsley, a gaffe is when a politician accidently tells the truth. That's certainly what happened to Mitt Romney on Tuesday, when in a rare moment of candor -- and, in his case, such moments are really, really rare -- he gave away the game.
Speaking in Michigan, Mr. Romney was asked about deficit reduction, and he absent-mindedly said something completely reasonable: ''If you just cut, if all you're thinking about doing is cutting spending, as you cut spending you'll slow down the economy.'' A-ha. So he believes that cutting government spending hurts growth, other things equal. 
The right's ideology police were, predictably, aghast; the Club for Growth quickly denounced the statement as showing that Mr. Romney is ''not a limited-government conservative.'' On the contrary, insisted the club, ''If we balanced the budget tomorrow on spending cuts alone, it would be fantastic for the economy.'' And a Romney spokesman tried to walk back the remark, claiming, ''The governor's point was that simply slashing the budget, with no affirmative pro-growth policies, is insufficient to get the economy turned around.''
But that's not what the candidate said, and it's very unlikely that it's what he meant. Almost surely, he is, in fact, a closet Keynesian.
How do we know this? Well, for one thing, Mr. Romney is not a stupid man. And while his grasp of world affairs does sometimes seem shaky, he has to be aware of the havoc austerity policies are wreaking in Greece, Ireland and elsewhere.
Beyond that, we know who he turns to for economic advice; heading the list are Glenn Hubbard of Columbia University and N. Gregory Mankiw of Harvard. While both men are loyal Republican spear-carriers -- each served for a time as chairman of George W. Bush's Council of Economic Advisers -- both also have long track records as professional economists. And what these track records suggest is that neither of them believes any of the propositions that have become litmus tests for would-be G.O.P. presidential candidates.
Consider Mr. Mankiw, in particular. Modern Republicans detest Keynes; Mr. Mankiw is the editor of a collection of papers titled ''New Keynesian Economics.'' In an early edition of his best-selling textbook, he dismissed supply-side economics -- the doctrine embraced by the sainted Ronald Reagan -- as the creation of ''charlatans and cranks.'' And, in 2009, he called for higher inflation as a solution to the economic crisis, a position anathema to Republicans like Representative Paul Ryan, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, who warn ominously about the evil of ''debasing'' our currency.
Given his advisers, then, it seems safe to assume that what Mr. Romney blurted out Tuesday reflected his real economic beliefs -- as opposed to the nonsense he pretends to believe, because it's what the Republican base wants to hear.
And therein lies the reason Mr. Romney acts the way he does, why he is running a campaign of almost pathological dishonesty.
For he is. Every one of the Romney campaign's major themes, from the attacks on President Obama for going around the world apologizing for America (he didn't), to the insistence that Romneycare and Obamacare are very different (they're virtually identical), to the claim that Mr. Obama has lost millions of jobs (which is only true if you count the first few months of his administration, before any of his policies had taken effect), is either an outright falsehood or deeply deceptive. Why the nonstop mendacity?
As I see it, it comes down to the cynicism underlying the whole enterprise. Once you've decided to hide your beliefs and say whatever you think will get you the nomination, to pretend to agree with people you privately believe are fools, why worry at all about truth?
What this diagnosis implies, of course, is that the many people on the right who don't trust Mr. Romney, who don't believe that he's truly committed to their political faith, are correct in their suspicions. He's playing a role, and it's anyone's guess what lies beneath the mask.
So should those who don't share the right's faith be comforted by the evidence that Mr. Romney doesn't believe anything he's saying? Should we, in particular, assume that, once elected, he would actually follow sensible economic policies? Alas, no.
For the cynicism and lack of moral courage that have been so evident in the campaign wouldn't suddenly vanish once Mr. Romney entered the Oval Office. If he doesn't dare disagree with economic nonsense now, why imagine that he would become willing to challenge that nonsense later? And bear in mind that if elected, he would be watched like a hawk for signs of apostasy by the very people he's trying so desperately to appease right now.
The truth is that Mr. Romney is so deeply committed to insincerity that neither side can trust him to do what it considers to be the right thing.

HEADLINE: Delusions About the Detroit Bailout

BYLINE: By STEVEN RATTNER. 
Steven Rattner, a longtime Wall Street executive and a contributing writer for Op-Ed, was the lead adviser on the Obama administration's auto task force in 2009.

 BODY:
WHEN Mitt Romney takes the podium at Ford Field in Detroit today, he's likely to include yet another sharp denunciation of the government's rescue of General Motors and Chrysler.
That Mr. Romney would traverse Michigan trashing a program that saved tens of thousands of jobs at the Detroit-based automakers doesn't necessarily mean he's politically tone-deaf.
After all, an NBC/Marist poll recently found that 50 percent of Michigan Republicans who were likely to vote opposed the government's actions (only 42 percent supported them). 
Mr. Romney may have the primary politics right -- though with a majority of Michigan voters supporting the rescue, he may want to pivot deftly before the general election in November. But on the substance he's dead wrong.
As a presidential aspirant, Mr. Romney evidently hasn't felt a need to be consistent or specific as to what should have been done to address the collapse of the auto industry starting in late 2008. But the gist is that the government should have stayed on the sidelines and allowed the companies to go through what he calls ''managed bankruptcies,'' financed by private capital.
That sounds like a wonderfully sensible approach -- except that it's utter fantasy. In late 2008 and early 2009, when G.M. and Chrysler had exhausted their liquidity, every scrap of private capital had fled to the sidelines.
I know this because the administration's auto task force, for which I was the lead adviser, spoke diligently to all conceivable providers of funds, and not one had the slightest interest in financing those companies on any terms. If Mr. Romney disagrees, he should come forward with specific names of willing investors in place of empty rhetoric. I predict that he won't be able to, because there aren't any.
Without government financing -- initiated by President George W. Bush in December 2008 -- the two companies would not have been able to pursue Chapter 11 reorganization. Instead they would have been forced to cease production, close their doors and lay off virtually all workers once their coffers ran dry.
Those shutdowns would have reverberated through the entire auto sector, causing innumerable suppliers almost immediately to stop operating too.
Despite the relative health of its balance sheet, even Ford would have been forced to close temporarily, because critical parts would have become unavailable. And service providers -- trucking companies, restaurants and more -- would have been severely affected.
More than a million jobs would have been lost, at least for a time. Michigan and the entire industrial Midwest would have been devastated.
I consider myself an ardent capitalist, and well recognize the risks of government intervention, particularly the ''moral hazard'' of rewarding failure and the scary prospect of politics' entering private sector decision-making.
But when markets fail, as they did for both autos and banks in 2008, government should have the ability -- in fact, the obligation -- to step in.
Interestingly, Mr. Romney's current principal Republican opponent, Rick Santorum, has opposed not only the auto rescue but also the help given to the banks, which Mr. Romney supported.
Yet Mr. Romney has become the lightning rod on autos because of the full-throated roar with which he has delivered his views, including an Op-Ed essay in The New York Times in November 2008 and another essay in The Detroit News 10 days ago.
Among Mr. Romney's grievances -- and to be fair, those of other opponents of the auto rescue -- is that the auto task force trampled on bankruptcy precedents and even the law to effect President Obama's plan of ''shared sacrifice'' by all stakeholders.
What he conveniently ignores is that the president's plan was litigated throughout the federal court system -- all the way to the Supreme Court, in the case of Chrysler -- without so much as a nod to the opponents from a single judge.
In retrospect, I recognize the emotions surrounding the decision to give members of the United Auto Workers company stock in exchange for resolving their health care claims. But the courts were emphatic that what we did was legal, because we remained true to a core principle of bankruptcy reorganization: every stakeholder received more from our plan than if the companies had been left to go bankrupt on their own.
Now, less than three years later, G.M. and Chrysler have markedly exceeded our expectations. Just a few days ago, G.M. reported an annual profit of $7.6 billion, and Chrysler is in the black as well. Both companies have increased their sales sharply, in part by making appealing new models.
And they are hiring new workers for the first time in many years. Michigan's unemployment rate has dropped far faster than the national average, though it is still painfully high.
All of this was accomplished at relatively low cost; taxpayers will receive back the vast preponderance of the $82 billion that was invested.
''I'd do it again,'' Mr. Bush said of the rescue in a recent speech. ''Sometimes circumstances get in the way of philosophy.'' Good thing he and Mr. Obama didn't take Mr. Romney's advice.

HEADLINE: Familiar Candidate Rallies His Supporters in Moscow

BYLINE: By ELLEN BARRY; Anastasia Sadovskaya and Glenn Kates contributed reporting.

 BODY:
MOSCOW -- Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin rallied his supporters on Thursday in a rare campaign appearance before a packed outdoor stadium, evoking Russia's historic battles against foreign invaders and telling the crowd that victory ''is in our genes, in our genetic code.''
Mr. Putin strode out in a ski parka and delivered a ferocious stem-winder, timed to an annual holiday on Thursday that honors the ''defenders of the fatherland'' and less than two weeks before the presidential election on March 4, which he is almost certain to win. 
''We will never allow anyone to interfere in our internal affairs,'' he said. ''We will not allow someone to impose their will on us, because we have our own will! It has helped us to conquer! We are a victorious people! It is in our genes, in our genetic code!''
The event, financed by Mr. Putin's campaign, at times appeared to pose an answer to a burgeoning antigovernment protest movement, which he has cast as an American-backed effort to undermine him. One placard read, ''I will not sell my conscience to the ambassador, I will give my vote to Putin'' -- probably a reference to the American ambassador, Michael A. McFaul, who has been accused on state-controlled television of trying to foment revolution.
''We call on everyone to unite around our country,'' Mr. Putin said. ''And we ask everyone not to look overseas, not to run to the left or to the side, and not to betray your homeland, but to be with us, work for Russia and love her as we do -- with our whole hearts.''
Thursday's event had a boisterous, holiday mood, with detachments of older women dressed as sunflowers and dancing to piped-in folk tunes. Organizers bolstered attendance by mobilizing state-linked organizations and workplaces; some participants said their bosses had told them to attend, and large groups had been bused in from outside Moscow. The police reported that 130,000 people were present at Luzhniki Stadium.
Support for Mr. Putin, which dipped to record lows in the aftermath of contested parliamentary elections in December, has steadily increased over the past two months.
Many who attended Thursday's event said they came because they feared that Russia would be drawn back into political and economic upheaval without Mr. Putin.
''We are afraid of rebellions,'' said Maria Lyulkova, 46. ''We are afraid of bloodshed because we all have children. We have near and dear whom we worry about. We want stability.''
Others said they would vote for him because there was no one better; in this election Mr. Putin faces three shopworn figures he has defeated in the past, and a newcomer, Mikhail D. Prokhorov, who poses no real threat.
Of 16 participants approached by a reporter on Thursday morning, 11 said their bosses had told them to attend -- though few expressed any resentment over this. Volunteers circulated through the crowd handing out sugary cups of tea and blini.
''You could say I am working at the Luzhniki demonstration, since my supervisors told me to come here,'' Vyacheslav Radnev said. ''But in principle, I support Putin -- around 70 percent. Do you remember how beautifully and skillfully he started out?''
But a young man who would give only his first name, Ramon, and who runs a department at a weapons factory, said he was so disillusioned by the political system that he would not vote at all on March 4. He came because he had received a series of promotions at the factory, and feared there would be repercussions if he did not attend.
''They told me to go, so I went,'' said Ramon, 23.
Most in the crowd, however, said they planned to vote for Mr. Putin, who has already served as Russia's paramount leader for 12 years -- as president and then prime minister -- and some were passionate. Oleg Filippov, 36, said Mr. Putin freed Russians from the painful economic and political turmoil of the 1990s. Mr. Filippov said that his father, a trained engineer, was forced to take a job loading freight but that since Mr. Putin came to power ''our life has seriously improved.'' Mr. Filippov said that he would vote for Mr. Putin now, and that in 2018, when his term ends, he would vote for whomever Mr. Putin endorsed.
''If he selects a successor, I will vote for his successor,'' he said. ''But these six years, they are clearly Putin's. There is no alternative.''

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: ''Our vote is for Putin,'' said a campaign sign for Vladimir V. Putin in Moscow on Thursday. (PHOTOGRAPH BY JAMES HILL FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

HEADLINE: The Listings

BYLINE: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

 BODY:
Theater
Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information: nytimes.com/theater.
Previews and Openings
'Assistance' (in previews; opens on Tuesday) Occupy the stage! This satire by Leslye Headland (the 2010 critical hit ''Bachelorette'') sets employees against a boss from hell. Directed by Trip Cullman, with Bobby Steggert, Michael Esper and Sue Jean Kim. Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200, playwrightshorizons.org. (David DeWitt)
'Beyond the Horizon' (in previews; opens on Sunday) Ciaran O'Reilly, who directed the Irish Rep revivals of ''The Emperor Jones'' and ''The Hairy Ape,'' returns to Eugene O'Neill with this staging of the playwright's first full-length work, a story of two brothers in love with the same woman. It won the Pulitzer Prize for Drama in 1920. Irish Repertory Theater, 132 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, irishrep.org. (David Rooney) 
'The Big Meal' (previews start on Thursday; opens on March 21) In what sounds like a modern-day take on Thornton Wilder, this new play traverses 80 years and five generations in the life of a typical suburban family. The director, Sam Gold, has found plenty of poetry in Annie Baker's forays into suburbia; let's see if he'll do the same for Dan LeFranc (''Sixty Miles to Silver Lake''). Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200, playwrightshorizons.org. (Eric Grode)
'Carrie' (in previews; opens on Thursday) Will it be another bloodbath or a fresh prom-night corsage this time around for the infamous musical adapted from the Stephen King novel? One of Broadway's most legendary flops in its 1988 debut, the show has been revised for this MCC Theater production by its original team, Michael Gore (composer), Dean Pitchford (lyricist) and Lawrence D. Cohen (author of the book and also screenwriter of the 1976 Brian De Palma film). Stafford Arima directs a cast that includes Molly Ranson as the telekinetic high school misfit and Marin Mazzie as her hellfire-preaching mother. Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 352-3101, mcctheater.org. (Rooney)
'Death of a Salesman' (in previews; opens on March 15) Following in the footsteps of Brian Dennehy, Dustin Hoffman, George C. Scott and Lee J. Cobb, just to name his Broadway predecessors in the role, Philip Seymour Hoffman slips on the careworn persona of Willy Loman in this revival of the Arthur Miller classic. Directed by Mike Nichols, the ensemble also features Linda Emond as Linda, Andrew Garfield (due on screen this summer in ''The Amazing Spider-Man'') as Biff, Bill Camp as Charley and John Glover as Ben. Ethel Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Rooney)
'Edward Albee's The Lady From Dubuque' (in previews; opens on March 5) As part of Signature's inaugural season in its new Frank Gehry-designed home, the company tackles one of Mr. Albee's more challenging plays with this rare revival of the 1980 work inspired by his reading of Elisabeth Kubler-Ross's ''On Death and Dying.'' David Esbjornson directs a cast led by Jane Alexander as the enigmatic title figure. Signature Center, 480 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 244-7529, signaturetheatre.org. (Rooney)
'Eternal Equinox' (previews start on Thursday; opens on March 7) He famously (and perhaps apocryphally) replied ''Because it's there'' when asked why he wanted to climb Mount Everest, but what were George Mallory's reasons for dropping in at the summer home of the Bloomsbury Group painters Vanessa Bell and Duncan Grant right before his third Everest attempt? Joyce Hokins Sachs's play, based on actual events and set on a fall day in 1923, looks to find out. 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212) 279-4200, 59e59.org. (Grode)
'Hot Lunch Apostles' (previews start on Thursday; opens on March 8) The long and fruitful collaboration between La MaMa and the Obie Award-winning company the Talking Band continues with a revival of Sidney Goldfarb's bawdy 1983 play about a troupe of carnival strippers who end up performing Bible stories. The folk-music veteran Loudon Wainwright III is on board as a performer, though presumably not as a stripper. Ellen Stewart Theater at La MaMa, 66 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 475-7710, lamama.org. (Grode)
'Hurt Village' (in previews; opens on Monday) Katori Hall (the Martin Luther King drama ''The Mountaintop'') is back in Memphis for this premiere, a tale of a teenage rapper, her family, their home in a housing project -- and the return of her father, an Iraq war veteran. With Ron Cephas Jones and Tonya Pinkins. Signature Center, 480 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 244-7529, signaturetheatre.org. (DeWitt)
'I Alice I' (previews start on Wednesday; opens on March 4) Fresh from the Abbey, Ireland's national theater, comes this story by the young Dublin-based company HotForTheater of two opinionated Irish woman (both named Alice) and the romance that has kept them afloat for more than a half-century. Amy Conroy, HotForTheater's artistic director, co-stars with Clare Barrett; Ms. Conroy also wrote and directed the piece. Irish Arts Center, 553 West 51st Street, Clinton, (866) 811-4111, irishartscenter.org. (Grode)
'An Iliad' (in previews; opens on March 6 and 7) The Tony-winning actors Denis O'Hare and Stephen Spinella play alternate performances of this new version of Homer's epic poem. Written by Mr. O'Hare and Lisa Peterson, who also directs, the production considers humanity's appetite for violence and destruction, contemplating how little has changed since the Trojan War. New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 279-4200, ticketcentral.com, nytw.org. (Rooney)
'Jesus Christ Superstar' (previews start on Thursday; opens on March 22) Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice's mildly revisionist rock gloss on the Gospels began life as a concept album, a format that the director Des McAnuff knows something about. (He won a Tony for guiding the Who's ''Tommy'' to the stage.) This production earned its share of hosanna hey-sannas at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Canada, where Mr. McAnuff is artistic director. Most of the Stratford cast has remained for the Broadway production, including Josh Young as Judas and Paul Nolan as the title character. Neil Simon Theater, 250 West 52nd Street, (877) 250-2929, ticketmaster.com. (Grode)
'Make Mine Manhattan' (previews start on Thursday; opens on March 4) Have the last 64 years been kind to this musical, which ran for more than a year in 1948? (Featuring a 20-something Sid Caesar in the cast undoubtedly helped.) UnsungMusicals aims to find out as it puts its theatrical defibrillators to this Big Apple-themed revue, which promises ''struggling actors, disgruntled theater critics and hapless out-of-towners.'' Are there any other kinds? Connelly Theater, 220 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 868-4444, smarttix.com. (Grode)
'Marrying George Clooney: Confessions From a Midlife Crisis' (previews start on Wednesday; opens on Thursday) Adapted from Amy Ferris's 2010 memoir of the same name, this three-character play drops in on three menopausal women at 3 a.m. In lieu of sleeping (with or without Mr. Clooney), the women Google old boyfriends, swap prescription drugs online and gripe about their mothers. CAP21 Black Box Theater, 18 West 18th Street, Flatiron district, (866) 811-4111, cap21.org. (Grode)
'Painting Churches' (in previews; opens on March 6) Carl Forsman stages the first New York revival of Tina Howe's 1983 comedy about parent-child relationships and the intersection of life and art. The Keen Company production stars Kathleen Chalfant and John Cunningham as the aging couple preparing to move to a Cape Cod beach house, and Kate Turnbull as the artist daughter who arrives to help them pack and paint their portrait. Clurman Theater at Theater Row, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Rooney)
'Once' (previews start on Tuesday; opens on March 18) Off Broadway transfers to Broadway are nothing new, and neither are musicals based on successful films, but this is a rare case of both of those phenomena happening at the same time. The scruffy 2006 romance about an Irish busker and a Czech immigrant bonding over music in Dublin has become a musical with the help of its original stars, Glen Hansard and Marketa Irglova (who wrote the music and lyrics), as well as John Tiffany and Steven Hoggett (the director and the choreographer of ''Black Watch''). Steve Kazee and Cristin Milioti star in the central roles. Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, 242 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Grode)
'Rated P for Parenthood' (in previews; opens on Wednesday) The Bugaboo set gets its own breezy four-actor musical, a la ''Menopause: The Musical'' and ''I Love You, You're Perfect, Now Change'' (a long-running hit in this same theater). Child rearing, from the arrival of the stork to the suddenly empty nest, is the topic this time. Westside Theater, 407 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Grode)
'Rutherford & Son' (in previews; opens on Monday) The solid Mint Theater first staged this 1912 family-business drama at a soon-to-be historic time -- September 2001 -- and now gives the play another chance, with some cast members from that production of more than a decade ago. Richard Corley directs the Githa Sowerby play. Mint Theater, 311 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (866) 811-4111, minttheater.org. (DeWitt)
'The Total Bent' (opens on Friday) Stew and Heidi Rodewald, the team behind ''Passing Strange,'' are back with this Public Lab presentation of a new musical about what press materials call ''the complicated space between the sacred and the profane,'' explored via the encounter between a black gospel prodigy from the American South and a white music producer from South London. Joanna Settle directs a cast that includes David Cale, William Jackson Harper and Vondie Curtis-Hall. Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555, publictheater.org. (Rooney)
'Tribes' (in previews; opens on March 4) Acclaimed in its 2010 premiere at the Royal Court Theater in London, Nina Raine's play brings David Cromer back to the same address where he staged his penetrating dissection of ''Our Town.'' His latest project is a provocative comedy about a young man born deaf into a family whose articulacy compounds his isolation. Things change when he begins a relationship with a woman also losing her hearing. The six-member cast features Mare Winningham. Barrow Street Theater, 27 Barrow Street, at Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 868-4444, smarttix.com. (Rooney)
Broadway
- 'Anything Goes' Kathleen Marshall's zesty revival of Cole Porter's hit-packed musical embodies the essence of escapist entertainment in the 1930s, when hard times called for bold smiles, tough wisecracks and flashy fantasies. Sutton Foster is sensational as the nightclub evangelist Reno Sweeney (2:30). Stephen Sondheim Theater, 124 West 43rd Street, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Ben Brantley)
- 'The Book of Mormon' This delightful collaboration between the creators of ''South Park'' (Trey Parker and Matt Stone) and the composer of ''Avenue Q'' (Robert Lopez) is blasphemous, scurrilous and as pure-hearted as a Rodgers and Hammerstein show. No musical has so successfully had it both ways since ''The Producers.'' Casey Nicholaw is the witty co-director (with Mr. Parker) and choreographer (2:15). Eugene O'Neill Theater, 230 West 49th Street, (800) 432-7250, telecharge.com. (Brantley)
'The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess' As the fatally conflicted Bess, the extraordinary Audra McDonald is a gale force of emotion in Diane Paulus's slimmed-down musical adaptation of the landmark 1935 opera. Otherwise, despite a likable performance from Norm Lewis as Porgy, this production feels cloudy and mild, only rarely acquiring the majesty of the opera that inspired it (2:30). Richard Rodgers Theater, 226 West 46th Street, (877) 250-2929, ticketmaster.com. (Brantley)
'Godspell' Oh, dear Lord: the beloved 1971 musical that turned biblical parables into teachable moments has been stuffed fruitcake-full of jokey contemporary allusions. Performed by a peppy young cast, the show is like being stuck in a rec room with kids who have been too reckless with the Red Bull (2:30). Circle in the Square Theater, 1633 Broadway, at 50th Street, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Charles Isherwood)
'How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying' Nick Jonas plays the amoral hero of Frank Loesser's 1961 musical about corporate ladder-climbing. Rob Ashford directed this largely charm-free revival (2:40). Al Hirschfeld Theater, 302 West 45th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Brantley)
- 'Other Desert Cities' Jon Robin Baitz's family drama is so good that you may not even realize how good it is while you're watching it. Joe Mantello directs a sublime cast that expertly elicits the pain and the comfort of blood ties: Stockard Channing, Rachel Griffiths, Stacy Keach, Judith Light and Justin Kirk (2:15). Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Brantley)
'Priscilla Queen of the Desert' The 1994 movie about Australian drag queens in the outback becomes a hyperactively splashy karaoke musical so desperate to show the audience a gaudy good time that the results are mostly enervating. Tony Sheldon brings some warmth as the transsexual Bernadette, but the show is mostly a riot of spangles, sequins and silly costumes (2:30). Palace Theater, 1564 Broadway, at 47th Street, (877) 250-2929, ticketmaster.com. (Isherwood)
'The Road to Mecca' A quiet, slow and ultimately powerful revival of Athol Fugard's three-character play about the inevitable and necessary apartness of artists. Rosemary Harris is wonderful, a study in subliminal radiance, as an aging South African sculptor under siege from the forces of conventionalism. Jim Dale and Carla Gugino provide strong support in Gordon Edelstein's production (2:30). American Airlines Theater, 227 West 42nd Street, (212) 719-1300, roundabouttheatre.org. (Brantley)
'Seminar' Alan Rickman is a virtuoso of disdain in Theresa Rebeck's shiny, facile comedy about an ego-shredding writing teacher. Full of efficiently mapped reversals, the play feels as if it were written according to the literary equivalent of a GPS device. Sam Gold directs a bright cast that includes Lily Rabe and Hamish Linklater (1:40). John Golden Theater, 252 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Brantley)
'Shatner's World: We Just Live in It ...' William Shatner -- the original Captain Kirk of ''Star Trek,'' later pitchman for Priceline.com -- reflects on his life and career in this often funny, sometimes rambling evening of anecdotes personal and professional. Strictly for Trekkies (1:35). Music Box Theater, 239 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Isherwood)
'Sister Act' When the good sisters of the Church of Philly Soul are rocking to raise the Gothic rafters, led by the radiant Patina Miller, all is right with this stage adaptation of the hit movie about a club singer hiding out as a nun. Otherwise, this story of a bad girl teaching some good ones how to get down is innocuous but generic musical theater (2:30). Broadway Theater, 1681 Broadway, at 53rd Street, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Isherwood)
'Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark' This retooled mega-expensive musical is no longer an ungodly, indecipherable mess. It's just a bore. Recommended for less-than-precocious children with a hundred dollars to burn (2:45). Foxwoods Theater, 213 West 42nd Street, (800) 745-3000, spidermanonbroadway.marvel.com. (Brantley)
- 'Venus in Fur' The incandescent Nina Arianda recreates her dazzling turn as an actress auditioning for the role of a 19th-century dominatrix in David Ives's seriously funny sex comedy about power games at an audition. Hugh Dancy holds his own as the writer-director who may be discovering more than he wants to know about the destabilizing nature of desire (1:45). Lyceum Theater, 149 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Isherwood)
'War Horse' This imported British weepie, adapted from Michael Morpurgo's children's book about a cavalry horse in World War I, has the most charismatic matinee idol seen in ages: that's Joey, the title character, a puppet brought to life-size life with ineffably theatrical magic (2:45). Vivian Beaumont Theater, 150 West 65th Street, (800) 432-7250, telecharge.com. (Brantley)
- 'Wit' Cynthia Nixon gives a large, lucid and delicate performance in this immaculately staged (and inevitably moving) revival of Margaret Edson's Pulitzer Prize-winning drama from 1998 about a terminally ill English professor. Lynne Meadow's smart and sensitive production magnifies the play's innate theatricality without compromising the hard emotional truth at its center (1:40). Samuel J. Friedman Theater, 261 West 47th Street, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Brantley)
Off Broadway
- 'The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs' The accomplished monologuist Mike Daisey weaves the story of the Apple co-founder's life and vision into a darker exploration of the troubling economic disparities that underlie our technology-obsessed age. Smart, engaging and funny, but be warned that you might have second thoughts about purchasing that next shiny gadget (1:50). Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555, publictheater.org. (Isherwood)
- 'And God Created Great Whales' Rinde Eckert's deeply sentimental, affecting and often funny portrait of an artist -- an opera composer -- in search of his own, rapidly deteriorating memory. Directed by David Schweizer and also starring Nora Cole, this revival of Mr. Eckert's 2000 performance piece uses music, flashcards and ''Moby-Dick'' in a fight against eroding time (1:20). Culture Project, 45 Bleecker Street, East Village, (866) 811-4111, cultureproject.org. (Brantley)
'The Berenstain Bears Live! In Family Matters, the Musical' The most famous bears since the three in the Goldilocks story are onstage in this adaptation of three of the titles in the long-running children's book series by Stan and Jan Berenstain. The show, by Michael Borton and Michael Slade, offers a pleasant hour for small theatergoers, with a pop-flavored score and actors who inhabit their fuzzy roles enthusiastically. But like the books, it's rather tame and tidy; after this many years of a formula, even the Berenstain cubs are starting to show their age. Saturday and Sunday only (:55). Marjorie S. Deane Little Theater, 5 West 63rd Street, (866) 811-4111, berenstainbearslive.com. (Laurel Graeber)
'Blood Knot' Scott Shepherd (''Gatz'') and Colman Domingo (''The Scottsboro Boys'') play brothers united by blood but divided by skin color in Athol Fugard's play about the brutalities of apartheid and, more universally, the way pernicious social forces can warp identity. Directed by the playwright himself, this first production in the Signature's season devoted to his work is more intellectually stimulating than emotionally engaging (2:30). Signature Center, 480 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 244-7529, signaturetheatre.org. (Isherwood)
'The Broken Heart' Selina Cartmell's gloom-shrouded production of this rarely staged tragedy by John Ford features a fine cast, but the air of woe foretold is so thick that it's hard to engage with the twisted tale of love and retribution (2:45). The Duke on 42nd Street, 229 West 42nd Street, (646) 223-3010, new42.org. (Isherwood)
'Chekhovek' This dramatization of nine Chekhov short stories is proficiently acted and directed, yet often more intriguing in theory than in execution (2:00). ArcLight Theater, 152 West 71st Street, (866) 811-4111, chekhovek.com. (Ken Jaworowski)
'CQ/CX' The playwright Gabe McKinley, a former news assistant at The New York Times, turns the newspaper's 2003 Jayson Blair scandal into a cautionary take of deceit, ambition and hubris. The play, briskly staged by David Leveaux for Atlantic Theater Company, has some insider details, but the work doesn't go much beyond the compelling narrative of a major journalistic fraud (2:15). Peter Norton Space, 555 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200, ticketcentral.com. (Frank Rizzo)
'The Devil's Music: The Life and Blues of Bessie Smith' Miche Braden plays the bawdy-talking, hooch-swilling Bessie Smith in this show that mixes Smith's songs with talk about her life, loves and career. That format seems a bit tired, but Ms. Braden gives it her all (1:20). St. Luke's Theater, 308 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Rachel Saltz)
'Early Plays' The weary sameness of life at sea, according to the young Eugene O'Neill, interpreted in a steady monotone by the avant-garde auteur Richard Maxwell. This willfully flat collaboration between Mr. Maxwell's New York City Players and the Wooster Group has occasional moments of melodrama-subverting clarity and more than occasional longueurs (1:30). St. Ann's Warehouse, 38 Water Street, at Dock Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn, (718) 254-8779, stannswarehouse.org. (Brantley)
- 'How I Learned to Drive' A first-rate revival of Paula Vogel's Pulitzer Prize winner. With Norbert Leo Butz and Elizabeth Reaser playing a predatory uncle and his precocious niece, one of the most discomfiting love stories in the American theater returns after 15 years with its power to rattle and stir undiluted. Kate Whoriskey directs (1:30). Second Stage Theater, 305 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 246-4422, 2st.com. (Brantley)
- 'The Inexplicable Redemption of Agent G' The pop-culture-drunk artists of Vampire Cowboys deliver an Asian exploitation drama that manages to be serious without sacrificing any silliness (1:30). Beckett Theater at Theater Row, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Jason Zinoman)
'Look Back in Anger' Sam Gold's stylized staging of John Osborne's 1956 drama about a working-class lad with the weight of a stifling social system on his shoulders wins points for ingenuity -- the stage is about three feet deep -- but in the crucial central role, Matthew Rhys (television's ''Brothers and Sisters'') never locates the genuine pain beneath the surface rage (2:10). Laura Pels Theater, Harold and Miriam Steinberg Center for Theater, 111 West 46th Street, (212) 352-3101, roundabouttheatre.org. (Isherwood)
'Poetic License' The vengeful young man in Jack Canfora's disturbing new drama makes Neil LaBute's manipulative misogynists look like sweethearts. This one-act play can be abrupt and not totally credible at times, but it is thought-provoking (1:20). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212) 279-4200, 59e59.org. (Anita Gates)
'Rent' Maybe they should call it ''Sublet.'' The young cast members who inhabit this premature revival of Jonathan Larson's watershed rock opera from 1996, directed by Michael Greif, never seem to feel truly at home. It is as if they're reluctant to make this show their own (2:30). New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Brantley)
'Richard III' Kevin Spacey entertainingly out-acts everybody onstage in Sam Mendes's valedictory production for the Anglo-American Bridge Project. Say what you will about Mr. Spacey's histrionic excesses, he provides a sustained (and intelligent) interpretation as Shakespeare's murderous crookback. The same cannot be said of Mr. Mendes's staging, a grab bag of postmodern gimmicks (3:00). Harvey Theater, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 651 Fulton Street, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100, bam.org. (Brantley)
'Russian Transport' Janeane Garofalo plays it straight, more or less, in Erika Sheffer's dark drama about the corrupting influence of a new Russian immigrant (the excellent Morgan Spector) on a Brooklyn family (2:10). Acorn Theater at Theater Row, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Isherwood)
- 'Rx' Kate Fodor's play about an affair between a work-weary editor (Marin Hinkle) and a pharmaceutical researcher (Stephen Kunken) is an engaging blend of gentle satire on our overprescribed culture and classic romantic comedy. Ethan McSweeny's sprightly production features fun supporting turns from Marylouise Burke and Elizabeth Rich (1:40). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212) 279-4200, primarystages.org. (Isherwood)
'Silence! The Musical' A silly, coarse musical spin on ''The Silence of the Lambs'' as pitched to obsessive fans (1:30). 9th Space Theater at Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 352-3101, silencethemusical.com. (Zinoman)
'Sistas: The Musical' The script is obvious, covering virtually every issue that might touch the lives of black women, but Dorothy Marcic's good-natured, low-budget musical is all about the songs. From ''Ain't Nobody's Business if I Do'' to ''Single Ladies,'' you could do a lot worse (1:30). St. Luke's Theater, 308 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com. (Gates)
'Sleep No More' Punchdrunk, a British site-specific theater company, has taken over three abandoned warehouses to enact the sorry sights of the murderous Macbeths' career as a movable orgy. The result suggests what might have happened if Stanley Kubrick (of ''The Shining'') had designed the Haunted Mansion at Disney World (2:00). The McKittrick Hotel, 530 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (866) 811-4111, sleepnomorenyc.com. (Brantley)
'Traces' An energizing evening of acrobatics from the Montreal troupe Seven Fingers. Think of it as cirque du cabaret, in which a group of distinctive talents gets to show off the physical equivalents of individual song stylings (1:30). Union Square Theater, 100 East 17th Street, (800) 982-2787, ticketmaster.com. (Brantley)
'Voca People' This show features space aliens, but it's really all about a cappella music. The visitors have crash-landed on Earth in a ship powered by music, and lots of singing must be done to refuel their ship. The eight singers sound pretty good, but most of the show consists of fragments of songs, which becomes annoying; only when the cast is allowed to cut loose and deliver an entire song -- the Doors' ''People Are Strange'' is a highlight -- do things reach their full potential (1:30). New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (800) 432-7250, telecharge.com. (Neil Genzlinger)
'Yosemite' Daniel Talbot's stormy dysfunctional family drama never entirely coheres persuasively (1:20). Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, 224 Waverly Place, at 11th Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 279-4200, ticketcentral.com. (Zinoman)
Off Off Broadway
- 'Bad Kid' It's the characters that stand out in this endearing solo show about growing up gay and goth in Texas (1:10). Axis Theater, 1 Sheridan Square, near Barrow Street, West Village, (212) 352-3101, theatermania.com. (Zinoman)
'Growing Up Gonzales' This one-man play about a Nuyorican family in the 1970s is part stand-up, part melodrama and part cultural tourism. Andres Chulisi Rodriguez alternates between playing two brothers: Cisco, the sweet-natured, slow younger brother, who we learn at the outset has recently died; and Johnny, the thuggish older sibling, who has discovered Cisco's journals after his brother's death. Quiet Cisco, it turns out, was quite the storyteller and has colorfully recreated the tragedies and farces of their fatherless childhood, including ridiculous stories about shoplifting raw chickens and imitating Bruce Lee (1:30). Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street, (212) 811-4111, growingupgonzales.com. (Catherine Rampell)
'I Killed My Mother' Andras Visky's bleak and insightful drama explores the hard-shelled, protective fantasies of Romanian orphans brought up in state institutions. Karin Coonrod's stark, poetic production is performed with feral fierceness by Andrew Hampton Livingston and the uncanny Melissa Lorraine Hawkins (1:30). La MaMa, 74A East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 475-7710, lamama.org. (Brantley)
'Mama, I Want to Sing' A largely new cast (seeded from the Gospel for Teens program in Harlem) gives full-throated life to this long-running gospel musical. Quibbles about the thin plot and questionable acting go out the window with each and every tune -- and there are plenty of them. Saturday only (2:00). The Dempsey Theater, 127 West 127th Street, Harlem, (212) 868-4444, mamafoundation.org. (Grode)
'That Ain't No Lady' The doyenne of New York's now-defunct annual outdoor drag festival, Wigstock, Lady Bunny purveys bawdy stand-up and pornographic pop song parodies in her first new cabaret act in 10 years. Looking like Dusty Springfield on steroids and introduced ''direct from the Port Authority men's room,'' the Lady and her show are definitely not for the prudish. But anyone feeling nostalgic for the seedy old days before Times Square became a tourist-friendly theme park will get a kick out of this evening of big hair and bad manners. Tuesday only (1:30). La Escuelita Cabaret Theater, 301 West 39th Street, (212) 631-0588, brownpapertickets.com. (Rooney)
- 'These Seven Sicknesses' Over the course of this ambitious adaptation of Sophocles' seven surviving plays, blood erupts from just about every orifice, onto just about every article of clothing and just about every square inch of the narrow stage. Sophocles purists may not be happy with some of the changes, but in the end this gory five-hour production -- which includes breaks for a pan-Asian dinner and dessert -- remains vibrant, entertaining and fresh. That's no small feat considering its marathon length and 2,400-year-old roots (5:00). Flea Theater, 41 White Street, TriBeCa, (212) 226-2407, theflea.org. (Rampell)

HEADLINE: The Methanol Alternative to Gasoline

BYLINE: By TOM RIDGE and MARY E. PETERS. 
Tom Ridge, a former governor of Pennsylvania, was secretary of homeland security from 2003 to 2005. Mary E. Peters was secretary of transportation from 2006 to 2009. They are members of the United States Energy Security Council.

 BODY:
PRESIDENT Obama recently called the United States the ''Saudi Arabia of natural gas'' and asserted that it was time for our oil-dominated transportation fuel market to open the door to natural gas. He's right. It would be cheaper for consumers and reduce the strategic importance of oil. But first we need cars that can run on methanol, a high-octane fuel made from converted natural gas.
We're producing more natural gas these days than we can use, thanks to new techniques to extract gas from shale. A recent report from the M.I.T. Energy Initiative, ''The Future of Natural Gas,'' called methanol ''the liquid fuel that is most efficiently and inexpensively produced from natural gas.'' China has already taken notice. Automakers there, like Chery, Geely and Shanghai Maple, have all introduced vehicles capable of running on methanol. Indeed, methanol is so much less costly per mile than gasoline that illegal fuel blending is rampant in China. 
Unfortunately, most cars sold in the United States offer consumers no choice beyond gasoline. The so-called flex fuel vehicles that are now on the market are warranted to operate only on gasoline and ethanol. If Congress were to enact an open fuel standard that required new cars to be warranted to run on all-alcohol fuels, including methanol, natural gas could compete with oil in the liquid fuels market. Producing these cars would cost about $100 more. And these fuels could be distributed through the current refueling infrastructure with only slight retrofits.
The current global spot price for methanol made from natural gas is $1.13 per gallon, without any subsidy. Methanol produces about half the energy per gallon as gasoline, so you need to burn twice as much to go just as far. But it is still cheaper than gas. It would cost approximately $3 today, including taxes, distribution and retail markup, to travel the same distance on methanol as on a gallon of gasoline, according to calculations by the Methanol Institute, a cost that is well below the current national average for gasoline. If the economics of natural gas change, a flex fuel vehicle could still run on methanol made from coal, biomass and possibly recycled carbon dioxide, if that technology proves economical.
Natural gas can also play other roles in the transportation sector. It can be used to generate electricity to charge the plug-in hybrids and electric vehicles that have entered the market. And it natural gas prices were to spike, there is always coal, nuclear or renewable power to rely upon for power generation. (Today, only 1 percent of the electricity in the United States is generated from oil.) Still, mass-market penetration of plug-in hybrid and electric vehicles will take some time, because of the high cost of automotive batteries.
Another way to run cars on natural gas is by using compressed natural gas, or C.N.G. These vehicles require a dedicated fuel line and a large gas canister in the trunk. However, the cost of converting a light-duty vehicle to C.N.G. is over $10,000. Such an upfront cost would be reasonable in high mileage users (over 35,000 miles per year) like taxis, buses and garbage trucks, but is too high for a typical car owner, and the return on investment would take many years, even with current low natural gas prices.
America is rich in natural gas and coal, but this is meaningless in terms of energy and economic security as long as our cars are unable to run on fuels made from these domestic commodities. Consumers should have a choice in the cost and type of fuel their vehicles require.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: On Hollywood's Night to Shine, Red Carpet Time For Ads, Too

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
THIS is one of those years when the public may be more familiar with the brands sponsoring the Academy Awards than the movies vying for best picture. Still, Madison Avenue is in a hooray-for-Hollywood mood, offering several reasons buying commercial time makes sense, despite an absence of huge hits among the nominees that suggests the ratings on Sunday could be lower than when blockbusters like ''Avatar'' or ''Titanic'' were contenders.
In fact, one sponsor, Diet Coke, will run a spot, by Wieden & Kennedy, that uses a version of the song ''Hooray for Hollywood'' on the soundtrack. In the spot, which is scheduled to be shown twice, Diet Coke is celebrated as the fuel for those behind the scenes who make movies, among them scriptwriters, stunt performers and sound effects artists. 
''The Oscars remains one of the very few high-impact programs when people are watching live,'' said William White, group brand director for Diet Coke and Coke Zero at Coca-Cola North America, part of the Coca-Cola Company.
''It's still appointment television,'' he added. ''We want to be there.''
Amplifying the impact is what is being called the second-screen phenomenon, whereby people watching live TV events are simultaneously interacting with friends and family on blogs, Facebook, Twitter and YouTube.
For instance, ''Diet Coke will be tweeting from the show,'' Mr. White said, to those who follow the brand's Twitter feed.
Beth Hirschhorn, chief marketing officer for another sponsor, MetLife, echoed Mr. White.
''Programming like this isn't just about volume,'' said Ms. Hirschhorn, referring to total viewership. ''It's about how deeply engaged consumers are while watching.''
''Many viewers tune in and watch from start to finish,'' she added, and when that happens, ''research tells us that message recall and comprehension are stronger.''
MetLife will run a commercial, by the MDC Partners agency Crispin Porter & Bogusky, that carries the theme ''MetLife. I can do this.'' It is part of a campaign that MetLife introduced during Super Bowl XLVI on NBC on Feb. 5 and continued during the Grammy Awards on CBS on Feb. 12.
Among the other blue-chip sponsors of the 84th Academy Awards, to be broadcast by ABC, are American Express, Anheuser-Busch InBev, AT&T, Walt Disney, Hyundai Motor America, Johnson & Johnson, Kraft Foods, McDonald's, Paramount Pictures, J.C. Penney, Procter & Gamble, Samsung and Sprint.
Samsung seems to believe the Oscars are so nice that it will be there twice, in the form of Samsung Electronics (Smart TV) and Samsung Telecommunications (Samsung Galaxy Note).
Another reason marketers like the Academy Awards is that ''it makes a statement'' to advertise ''in a show of that kind of stature,'' said Andy Goeler, vice president for imports, crafts and specialties at the Anheuser-Busch division of Anheuser-Busch InBev, which plans to run a new commercial for Stella Artois beer by the Mother agency.
''Our consumer base is sophisticated,'' Mr. Goeler said of Stella Artois, ''and a platform like the Academy Awards aligns perfectly with that audience, a sophisticated, upscale audience.''
Hyundai Motor America intends to devote four of the seven commercials it is to run during the show -- all of them by the Innocean Worldwide Americas agency -- to a luxury model, the 2012 Azera sedan, that with a sticker price of around $32,000 is aimed at the affluent viewers of the Oscars. Two Azera spots were directed by an Oscar nominee, the movie director Wes Anderson, and all seven spots are narrated by an Oscar winner, the actor Jeff Bridges.
The types of people who watch the Academy Awards also make the show appealing to marketers that want to burnish their images with an audience that includes many so-called influencers, whose perceptions are important in shaping brand image.
For example, of the two commercials that McDonald's will run, both by the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, one is part of a series that salutes the farmers who supply the company with ingredients like lettuce.
''Customers more and more are interested in the food they eat,'' said Neil Golden, senior vice president and chief marketing officer at McDonald's, and ''we want to make sure we tell the story of the care and attention we take in every step'' of making menu items.
''The Academy Awards audience is a fabulous audience,'' Mr. Golden said. ''There is an opportunity with high-profile programming to better engage consumers with the brand.''
The other McDonald's commercial, which is new, offers a twist on the old game of ''He loves me, he loves me not,'' courtesy of a couple of boxes of the chain's French fries.
''The movies are about storytelling,'' said Marlena Peleo-Lazar, chief creative officer at McDonald's, ''and the advertising we do tells a story.''
Social media make ''our ability to engage in a conversation'' about those stories easier, she added.
The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences seeks to ensure that the atmosphere of the show will appeal to the kinds of viewers the sponsors seek. The academy limits the number of commercials and network promotions that ABC can run each hour of the show.
And the academy reviews the contents of each spot for acceptability, separate from the scrutiny of the standards and practices department at ABC.
As a result, the types of racy commercials that raised eyebrows during the Super Bowl, for advertisers like Go Daddy and Teleflora, are about as likely to appear during the Oscars as a little-known nominee like ''The Tree of Life'' is to win best picture.

LENGTH: 363 words

HEADLINE: Sound Rule, With a Serious Flaw

 BODY:
A year ago, we praised the Obama Treasury Department for championing a new rule to protect vulnerable Americans from rapacious creditors. Before the rule is finalized, the administration must fix a provision that could still cause severe hardships. 
The law bars creditors from seizing Social Security payments and other federal benefits for veterans, the poor, the aged and the disabled. But banks often said they could not determine the source of customers' deposits and allowed creditors to garnish accounts containing federal funds. The new rule adds electronic tags to automatically deposited government payments and requires banks to protect tagged deposits made in the prior two months.
Here's the issue: The new rule will still allow seizure of all funds in an account if a state is trying to collect unpaid child support. That may seem to be a good way to get tough on deadbeat dads, but it will cause undue harm.
In a letter to the commissioner of Social Security, the National Consumer Law Center and 72 other advocacy groups pointed out that 70 percent of uncollected child support is owed by people who live below the poverty line and much of the debt arose because support obligations were not revised when the debtor became disabled, unemployed or incarcerated. Since the debts are often old, the amounts have been inflated by interest and penalties.
To both collect the debts and avoid driving these debtors into complete destitution, the law allows Social Security to withhold up to 65 percent of a benefit to cover unpaid child support -- and to pay the recipient the rest. Recipients of reduced benefits have been able to shield the remainder by receiving their payment via paper check and simply cashing it. Starting next year, all government benefits will be automatically deposited. If the rule is not amended, the full amount will be subject to seizure.
The way to fix the problem is to rework the garnishment rule so that it treats child support debts the same way it treats other debts. Fixing the rule would not excuse nonpayment of child support. Rather, it would achieve what the law intended by ensuring that no one is impoverished by ruthless debt collection.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: In a Gamble For Cash, Sears Plans To Sell Stores

BYLINE: By PETER EAVIS

 BODY:
Sears Holdings moved on Thursday to allay fears that it could run low on cash this year, announcing plans to sell stores in transactions that the company says could raise nearly $800 million.
But the deals also highlight the major challenges that Sears faces as it tries to stop a multiyear slump in its operations, analysts said.
Sears may be giving up its most profitable stores in exchange for a quick cash infusion today. In one of the transactions, Sears also expects current shareholders to foot the bill, potentially leaving them more exposed to the troubled retailer. 
''As a matter of fact, spinoffs like these could leave Sears with a very unprofitable core Sears U.S. business,'' said Mary Ross Gilbert, an analyst with Imperial Capital, a brokerage firm.
These moves come as the company's largest investor, its chairman, Edward S. Lampert, has been increasing his personal stake in the company. Mr. Lampert engineered the merger of Kmart and Sears, Roebuck, in a $11 billion deal in late 2004, and his hedge funds now own 61 percent of the stock.
The price of Sears shares jumped 18.7 percent on Thursday, to $61.80, even as the company reported weak financial results.
For the year, Sears reported a loss of $3.14 billion, a number that included $2.7 billion of charges, compared with a profit of $133 million for 2010. The fourth quarter had a $2.44 billion loss, compared with a profit of $382 million the previous year.
The company also reported an annual decline in revenue, its fifth in a row. Such trends are a stark reminder that Sears's problems have deepened since it came under Mr. Lampert's control.
Critics say that under Mr. Lampert the company has not spent enough to update its stores and that now, in the face of intense competition, Sears is in danger of permanently falling out of shoppers' favor.
In a letter to shareholders, Mr. Lampert said: ''We made it through the financial crisis and the housing crisis. Now we intend to make it through our current challenges and restore confidence in the company.''
As Sears's problems have persisted, all eyes are on its cash flows as investors weigh its chances of survival. The company tacitly acknowledged the attention on its cash on Thursday.
It does not normally hold conference calls to discuss financial results, but Lou D'Ambrosio, Sears's chief executive, said one of the reasons it did so after the latest earnings release was ''to make our funding strategy clear.''
Sears's operations were most likely a drain on cash last year, said Ms. Ross Gilbert.
Sears said it had $277 million of adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, or Ebitda. But Ms. Ross Gilbert said that excluded $383 million of cash contributions to its pensions. Including that would put Ebitda deep in negative territory. And if Sears's top line continues to decline, the loss could be even deeper this year.
Analysts are also keeping an eye on Sears's suppliers, as well as the companies, called factors, that make cash advances to the suppliers based on the goods they sell to Sears. If vendors and factors become wary of Sears's creditworthiness, the retailer may have to pay suppliers cash upfront for goods, which could be a huge drain on liquidity.
''The focus of the call was for the vendors, and steps taken were all focused on near-term cash generation,'' said Gary Balter, a retail analyst with Credit Suisse.
But Sears also has sizable cash sources. It had about $2.5 billion available on two credit lines at the end of January, though the company may draw much of that this fall as it spends large amounts stocking its stores ahead of the holidays.
This is where the property sales announced Thursday become important. If they all occur, and Sears succeeds in cutting costs and slashing inventory, the company could have a sizable cash cushion in the fall. That would bolster confidence and perhaps persuade suppliers not to demand upfront cash payments for their goods.
One of the asset sales appears to be in the bag. General Growth Properties, a mall operator, has agreed to buy 11 Sears properties, which will raise $270 million.
However, the other deal - which aims to raise as much as $500 million and is slated for later this year - is less straightforward. In effect, Sears aims to sell its smaller Hometown and Outlet stores to any interested Sears shareholders. The company said Mr. Lampert's hedge funds expected to participate and exercise their rights in full.
But the danger is that Sears may be selling some of its best properties, which could mean even worse operating results in the future. On the conference call on Thursday, a Sears executive declined to say what proportion of its stores was profitable.
The outgoing Hometown and Outlet stores were profitable last year, producing as much as $80 million of Ebitda, Sears said.
The big question now is how many more of these types of sales Sears could do. More than 120 properties cannot be sold because they are effectively locked in an insurance subsidiary. Others may be harder to sell because they are in less attractive malls.
Furthermore, agreements with Sears's creditors may contain restrictions on assets sales. A Sears spokeswoman said, ''The domestic credit agreement contains customary limitations on asset sales.'' But she added, ''We do not believe our debt agreements place material restrictions on us that would prevent us from taking value-adding actions, such as those announced today.''
At any rate, Ms. Ross Gilbert expects the cash-raising measures to alleviate the concerns of Sears's suppliers for now. But she added, ''They basically buy Sears another year.''
This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
